item.title: Teva Expands in Mexico
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Teva has announced the $2.3B acquisition of Rimsa (approx. 10x revenue), which will add manufacturing and distribution capabilities in Mexico. The deal will boster earnings starting from Q1:17 (Copaxone 40mg lost of patent). According to Teva, the majority of the Rimsa business (>90% of revenue) consists of branded products, and over 60% of the business is driven by the private market (ie, not government), which is the most profitable segment of the pharmaceutical market in Mexico.
Rationale for the deal
- Expansion in emerging markets, and Mexico in particular, has been a priority for Teva.
- The acquisition will provide the company with a growing and profitable business, as well as a large sales platform (>900 sales reps) to help Teva commercialize products that it has been developing for the Mexican market (and some products that will come with the Allergan Generics acquisition).
Rimasa Snapshot
Privately-held pharma company
HQ: Mexico
2014 revenur: £227M

item.title: AEZS-108 Met Its Primary End Point For Its Ph2 Trial In Post Chemo mCRPC Setting
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Aeterna Zentaris reported its AEZS-108 (zoptarelin doxorubicin) met the primary endpoint of the Ph2 trial in the post chemo mCRPC setting. The primary endpoint was Clinical Benefit (CB) defined as remaining progression-free by RECIST and Prostate Specific Antigen (PSA) after treatment for 12+ weeks. The data was presented at ECC 2015 by Dr. Jacek Pinski during poster session. Zoptarelin doxorubicin is also being evaluated in Ph3 for endometrial cancer. The second interim results are scheduled to release this month.
Zoptarelin doxorubicin is a New Chemical entity composed of a targeted synthetic peptide carrier linked to doxorubicin that aims to an improved, targeted delivery of doxorubicin with improved benefit risk profile.
Study Design

This was a single-arm Simon Optimum design Phase 2 study of zoptarelin doxorubicin in 25 patients with CRPC. Patients received zoptarelin doxorubicin (210 mg/m2) intravenously over 2 hours, every 3 weeks. The primary endpoint was CB, defined as remaining progression-free by RECIST and PSA after treatment for 12+ weeks. Secondary endpoints were progression free survival (PFS), best overall response, toxicity, pain and overall survival (OS).
Results
Twenty patients had measurable disease, with a median of 1 prior chemotherapy regimens and a median PSA of 255.8 ng/ml. Eleven patients experienced CB; 13 patients achieved stable disease. Median PFS and OS were 4.4 months (95% CI: 3.6, 5.5) and 6 months (95% CI: 4.2, 10.7) respectively. Forty-four percent of patients demonstrated improvement of pain score at 12 weeks. Maximal PSA response was stable in 20 patients. Zoptarelin doxorubicin demonstrated good tolerability with grade 3-4 hematologic (n=7) and grade 3 blood and lymphatic system disorders (n=5) adverse events as the most common events.
A
Other Pipeline
Source: ECC 2015 Vienna, Aeterna Zentaris Press Release

item.title: Merck's Consumer Health Counts on LatAm to Grow
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Consumer Health is the fastest growing business at Merck. The division reported net Q2 sales of €227.6M, (+16% organic growth vs the year-earlier period). All global strategic brands outperformed with Neurobion, Dolo-Neurobion and Femibion being key contributors. Key geographies with strong growth momentum were Chile and Mexico for Latin America. Two days ago, at the Financial Times Latin America Healthcare & Life Sciences Summit, Management stressed that 'along with a growing consumer demand, Latin America sees a rise in the need for healthcare products and a trend towards consumer goods making daily life more convenient'.
In Brazil,
the Floratil consumerization approach drove a 34% net sales growth in 2014 versus 2013 and the franchise is expected to be the second fastest growing in the Latin American portfolio by the end of the decade. Bion is expected to become the fastest growing brand in the region, after the successful launch of Bion3 in 2014 in Brazil.
In Chile,
thanks to a consumer approach with focus on digital already initiated in 2010, Bion3 has become the 2nd biggest OTC brand and the best-selling multivitamin with a market share of ~60%.

item.title: TELESTAR Data At ESMO - Key Takeaways
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: While we were already aware that the Phase III TELESTAR study for Telotristat etiprate was positive, M.Kulke presented a more detailed view of the data at ESMO. He commented on how Telotristat etiprate significantly reduced bowel movement frequency in patients with carcinoid syndrome taking SSAs, a durable response was observed in 44% and 42% of patients receiving telotristat etiprate 250 mg TID and telotristat etiprate 500 mg TID, respectively, versus 20% of patients on placebo. Prof. Cunningham (The Royal Marsden, UK) raised few interesting comments to Kulke's data presentation and in particular the need for more data to clarify the impact on patients Quality Of Life and a careful assessment of health economic evaluation to introduce the treatment into clinical practice.
M.Kulke – TELESTAR presentation
Statistical Design:
  • Primary endpoint: Daily BM frequency averaged over 12-week, double-blind treatment phase
  • Study powered with alpha of 0.025 to detect a treatment difference of –1.5 BM/day for each telotristat etiprate group compared with placebo
  • A blocked Wilcoxon rank-sum statistic (stratified by baseline urinary 5-HIAA levels) was used as the primary method to compare BM frequency between telotristat etiprate and placebo, and a Hodges–Lehmann estimator was used to measure treatment-group differences
Additional secondary Endpoints:
Reductions in flushing and abdominal pain were greater on treatment with telotristat etiprate than placebo; however, differences were not statistically significant
  • Only 39% of patients had at least 2 episodes of flushing per day
  • Only 39% of patients had a mean abdominal pain severity score ≥3 (scale 1-10) at baseline
CONCLUSIONS
  • Telotristat etiprate significantly reduced bowel movement frequency in patients with carcinoid syndrome taking SSAs
    • Durable response was observed in 44% and 42% of patients receiving telotristat etiprate 250 mg TID and telotristat etiprate 500 mg TID, respectively, versus 20% of patients on placebo
  • Telotristat etiprate had a favorable safety profile and was well tolerated in this study
  • Telotristat etiprate significantly reduced urinary 5-HIAA in patients with carcinoid syndrome, suggesting effective inhibition of intratumoral TPH
  • Telotristat etiprate represents a promising new potential treatment approach for patients with carcinoid syndrome
Cunningham Commentary to the TELESTAR Data

item.title: A "New" Smart Capsule Engineered to Deliver Medications Directly to the Colon
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Inventors of the capsule are part of the Purdue University in Indiana. The researchers claim that the device tackles the complex problem of drug delivery to the lower part of the GI tract, and could potentially make drug treatment for Crohn's disease and irritable bowel syndrome more effective. The team has outlined being currently working with a 'private biomedical company' in an effort to start clinical trials.
The device is comprised of two parts, one carrying a drug payload and the other housing electronics.
The medication is released after the capsule makes its eight hour journey through the harsh acidity of the stomach and 20 feet of small intestine, ensuring its drug payload reaches the colon intact.
Source: http://linkis.com/www.reuters.com/arti/1DHsz

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Synthetic Biologics Appoints Manufacturing Executive
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Management has announced that Raymond D. Stapleton, PhD, has joined as Senior Vice President, Manufacturing. He will lead the manufacturing team as the Company begins to prepare for late-stage clinical trials for SYN-010 (for IBS-C) and SYN-004 (for C. difficile), and continues to move its monoclonal antibody (mAb) program forward to address Pertussis.
Pharmaceutical and biotechnology executive with over 15 years of experience at Merck & Co., Inc., in manufacturing, operations, quality, science, technology, engineering and process development.
He most recently served as Executive Director, Global Vaccine Technology and Engineering. During his tenure at Merck, Dr. Stapleton contributed to the scale up, tech transfer and manufacturing product launch of multiple billion dollar franchises including ISENTRESS® (oral solid dosage for AIDs), GARDASIL® (HPV vaccine), KEYTRUDA® (anti-PD-1 cancer mAb therapy), and performed process development for the cholesterol lowering therapy MEVACOR® (lovastatin).
Source: Synthetic Biologics

item.title: Novartis Symposia At ESMO - Key Takeaways
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Novartis leveraged on the new RADIANT-4 data and future everolimus positioning with two key symposia on NET treatment at ESMO 2015. Novartis is clearly trying to position everolimus as a strong player in NET, and in particular in lung NET - also considering Afinitor is going to lose traction in other indications (e.g. RCC). Novartis is trying to establish the right line of treatment for everolimus in NET but is clearly facing challenges from SSA as well as NETTER-1/Lutathera data.
Key takeaways:
  • While it is widely accepted that high dose octreotide can be used as a valid treatment option for progressive GEP NET , it was the first time that data were presented in a NVS symposium detailing a very good safety profile
  • Novartis has sent strong messaging to support the safety of everolimus after chemotherapy and after PRRT - data presented seem like NVS might try and push the usage of Lutathera therapy after everolimus usage. We need to anticipate what Novartis will do in terms of positioning its own NET portfolio relative to that of AAA. Further data (Poster 229, academic sponsored, no NVS) also suggested a benefit of SSA/Everolimus prior to PRRT therapy.
  • Marketing materials of Sandostatin LAR and Afinitor were presented alongside at Novartis booth – with no clear indication of any RADIANT- 4 results. As we already predicted at the Global Somatuline Forum (September 18th) Novartis is likely to invest heavily behind the new indications bundling everolimus promotion alongside Sandostatin LAR. We need to closely monitor this aspect at the coming up congresses.
NOVARTIS SYMPOSIUM, ‘Challenges of Treating Rare Diseases’, Friday 23th
The symposium focused on NET and adult Soft Tissue Sarcoma (aSTS – Pazopanib treatment). The intro was given by Stefan Sleijfer that described STS and NET as rare heterogeneous diseases and explained how applying lessons learnt from the clinical trials, with regards to inclusion of homogeneous NET patient populations, may produce meaningful results. Also, although OS is considered the preferred endpoint for clinical trials, it is a critical limiting factor when patient accrual is difficult (both in NET and aSTS) – he therefore commented on how other endpoints, such as time to clinical deterioration and PROs, should be considered.
The next two speakers presented ‘real life’ case studies to address treatment optimisation and long –term strategies for NET patients.
‘Question and controversies in NET: Finding the Right Therapy for the Right Patients in Real Life’ (Rachel Riechelmann)
Dr. Riechelmann presented a case of a 49 yr old men that presented with well-differentiated pNET, with primary tumor considered inoperable. The patient was investigated as strong MEN1 suspected.
The patient treatment was discussed – few highlights:
  • CapOx in pNET – a retrospective experience
  • The safety of everolimus after chemotherapy and after PRRT - data presented seem like NVS might try and push the usage of Lutathera therapy after everolimus usage.
  • Everolimus was shown to provide well-tolerated disease stabilization in this MEN1-related functioning pNET case.
  • This patient case demonstrated the importance of proactively managing adverse events with everolimus, including atypical infections, to support long-term use.
Addressing Current Issues in GI NET: Emerging Evidence to Optimize Treatment (Diego Ferone)
The second patient case had a discrepancy in grade between the primary tumor and the metastases. Ferone addressed two points in the treatment management of the case presented:
  • Functional PET imaging is recommended for NET diagnosis
  • High-dose octreotide is a valid treatment option for progressive GEP NET while maintaining a very good safety profile
MANAGING NETS IN 2015 (prIME Oncology) – A MULTIDIMENSIONAL CHALLENGE , Sunday 25th
Yao kicked the symposium off describing how to control tumor growth in well differentiated NETs – he went through the already known PROMID, CLARINET, Sunitinib Phase III, SWOG S0518, RADIANT-1, 3 and 4 data – summary of the positioning of the different treatment options is shown below.
K.Oberg gave a very interesting overview on managing symptoms of hormone excess. Key takeaways:
  • SSAs will remain the first line therapy for functioning NETs
  • In patients with carcinoid syndrome Telotristat etiprate, once approved, will be added to SSA for symptom control
  • Everolimus has demonstrated symptomatic control in hypoglycaemia (insulinoma) but also glucanoma and VIPoma
  • Interferon can be added to SSA for symptom control in patients with carcinoid syndrome or WDHA-syndrome
  • PRRT gives significant symptom control in NET
Fazio concluded the session presenting two clinical cases:
Case 1: Non functioning lung carcinoid (treatment sequence: surgery – relapse – everolimus+SSA – Chemo – PRRT)
Case 2: Functioning small bowel NET (treatment sequence: octreotide- PRRT and then octreotide usage)
NOVARTIS MARKETING MATERIALS
Marketing materials of Sandostatin LAR and Afinitor were presented alongside at Novartis booth – with no clear indication of any RADIANT- 4 materials. We need to evaluate if Novartis is likely to invest heavily behind the new indications bundling everolimus promotion alongside Sandostatin LAR. Interesting info on nurses support and patients support on the marketing panel. Novartis also had two panels marketing the NET Alliance resource library for patients and caregivers - MyNET Manager App, available on AppStore and GooglePlay.

item.title: BLU-554 For HCC Received FDA's Orphan Drug Designation
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Blueprint Medicines has received orphan drug designation to its BLU-554 for HCC. BLU-554, a selective FGFR4 inhibitor, is currently being evaluated in Ph1 for HCC and cholangiocarcinoma. The Ph1 trial will enroll patients at multiple centres in the US, EU, and Asia.
About BLU-554
BLU-554 is a selective FGFR4 inhibitor. Aberrantly activated signalling of FGFR4 may be a key driver in up to 30% of HCC patients and may also play a role in a subset of patients with cholangiocarcinoma. BLU554 has been shown to have significant anti-tumour activity in preclinical models of HCC driven by aberrant FGFR4 signalling. The Ph1 trial is expected to enroll 50 patients with advanced unresectable HCC and an additional 10 patieints with advanced unresectable cholangiocarcinoma.
About Blueprint Medicines - an ocncology fous biotech company
Blueprint is headquartered in Cambridge, Massachusetts, the US. The operating loss of the company was US$39.7 million in FY2014, compared to an operating loss of US$21 million in FY2013. The net loss of the company was US$40.3 million in FY2014, compared to a net loss of US$20.9 million in FY2013. The company reported revenues of US$2.7 million for the second quarter ended June 2015, compared to a revenue of US$0.7 million the previous quarter. The company has completed an initial IPO of 9,367,708 shares of its common stock at a price of USD18 per share, for gross proceeds of US168.8m.
The company's development focuses on discovery for selective kinase inhibitors for genomically defined cancer subsets. It has developed a platform that combines kinase inhibitors with genomics, which helps to develop selective compounds against clear genomic driver targets. Blueprint identifies drug targets by sequencing cancers and mining public data with new genome analysis algorithms. The company’s programs include KIT D816V selective inhibitor, FGFR4 selective inhibitor, and other programs. It has partnership with two genomic and cancer research institutions such as the Massachusetts General Hospital Cancer Center and Wellcome Trust Sanger Institute.
BLU-285 in Unresectable and Treatment-Resistant GIST
BLU-285 is a potent and selective inhibitor of KIT Exon 17 and PDGFR-alpha D842V mutants, which are key disease drivers of metastatic and treatment-resistant GIST. GIST is the most common form of sarcoma of the gastrointestinal tract. Patients with the KIT Exon 17 and PDGFR-alpha D842V mutants are not adequately treated with existing therapies.
In this Phase 1 trial, Blueprint Medicines plans to enroll 60 patients with GIST or other relapsed or refractory solid tumors at multiple sites in the U.S., EU and Asia. The trial will test the safety and tolerability of escalating doses of BLU-285, with the goal of establishing an MTD, or a recommended dose if the MTD is not achieved. Once the MTD or recommended dose has been established, patients with treatment-resistant GIST and PDGFR-alpha D842V mutant GIST will be enrolled in expansion cohorts. Additional study objectives include assessing early signs of biological activity using disease-specific biomarkers and clinical efficacy as measured by response rate by RECIST modified for GIST.
Source: Blueprint Medicines Press Release

item.title: Borealis-2 Trial For OncoGenex's Apatorsen Completed Enrollment For Second Line Metastatic Bladder Cancer
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: OncoGenex announced completion of patient enrolment of a target 200 patients in Borealis-2 clinical trial evaluating Apatorsen in 2nd line metastatic bladder cancer. This is an investigator sponsored randomized Ph2 trial that is designed to evaluate apatorsen in combination with docetaxel in the 2nd line setting. Borealis-2 is sponsored by Hoosier Oncology Group and is being conducted at 27 sites across the United States.
Clinical Evidence
Data from the Borealis-1 trial previously reported at the ASCO earlier this year showed that metastatic bladder cancer patients with poor prognostic features (low performance status, liver involvement, low hemoglobin and high alkaline phosphatase) showed a potential survival benefit with apatorsen 600mg added to first-line chemotherapy (HR = 0.72) compared to chemotherapy alone. Patients in the trial with a Karnofsky Performance Status of 80 percent or less, a common indicator of poor prognosis, experienced a 50 percent reduction in risk of death with the addition of apatorsen therapy (HR = 0.50). Based on findings from the Borealis 1 trial, OncoGenex and the Hoosier Oncology Group plan to evaluate overall survival in patients with poor prognostic factors in the Borealis-2 trial.
ClinicalTrials.gov Identifier:NCT01780545
Source: OncoGenex Press Release 30 Sept

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: RADIANT-4 Data At ESMO - Key Takeaways
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The RADIANT-4 data were presented by J.Yao at ESMO 2015 and showed that treatment with everolimus is associated with a 52% improvement in median PFS compared with placebo in patients with advanced lung and GI NETs. While we are aware of the delay in tumor growth that everolimus plays in pNET, this is the first time that data were conclusively showing its effectiveness in other NET sites, and in particular lung NETs. Novartis is likely therefore to expand Everolimus’s label based on the RADIANT-4 results and focus on positioning the drug as a major treatment option for NET patients, especially considering the new threats that Afinitor is going to face in other indications such as RCC (also data presented at ESMO). Based on the released data, filing in non-functioning GI and lung NET is still believed to take place in 2015 with estimated approval in 2H 2016.

Looking ahead we need to closely monitor and understand:

  1. Novartis’ strategy to market Afinitor in the new indication and weight the threat of Novartis bundling it with Sandostatin LAR;
  2. The role everolimus could play in symptom control;
  3. The line of treatment for everolimus - while physicians still believe that SSA will remain first line of treatment, the debate of treatment for progressive patients will remain.
RADIANT-4 DATA

In RADIANT-4, 302 patients with progressive, well-differentiated, nonfunctional lung/GI NETs were stratified by tumor origin, WHO performance status (PS), and prior somatostatin analog treatment, then randomized 2:1 to receive best supportive care plus either everolimus at 10 mg per day (n = 205) or placebo (n = 97). Patient median age was 63 years, 53% of patients were female, and 76% were Caucasian. Disease status was grade 1/grade 2 in 64% and 35% of patients, respectively, and WHO PS was 0 in 74% or 1 in 26% of patients. The most commonly reported tumor sites were the lung in 30%, and the ileum in 24% of patients. The two arms were well balanced regarding prior treatment; 53% versus 56% of patients in the everolimus and placebo groups respectively had received prior somatostatin analog therapy; 26% versus 24% had received chemotherapy, and 22% versus 20% had undergone previous loco-regional and radiotherapy.

The primary endpoint of PFS as assessed by central radiology review was a median 11.0 months with everolimus (95% CI, 9.23–13.31) compared with 3.9 months with placebo (95% CI, 3.58–7.43). A 52% reduction in the relative risk of disease progression or death was observed with everolimus versus placebo (HR, 0.48; 95% CI, 0.35–0.67; P < .001). The “robust benefit” was confirmed in the investigator-assessed PFS, which was 14.0 months (95% CI, 11.24–17.71) compared with 5.5 months (95% CI, 3.71–7.39) with placebo (HR, 0.39; 95% CI, 0.28–0.54; P < .001).
Secondary endpoints included overall survival (OS), objective response rate (ORR), disease control rate (DCR), and safety. ORR by central review showed no complete response, but 4 (2%) of everolimus patients and one placebo patient showed partial response. DCR was 82% with everolimus versus 65% with placebo. Progressive disease was reported for 9% of everolimus patients compared with 27% of patients receiving placebo.
A pre-planned interim OS analysis performed with 37% of the information fraction favored everolimus (HR, 0.64; 95% CI, 0.40–1.05; P = .037); however, OS difference did not achieve statistical significance. Next interim analysis is expected in 2016.
Safety profile was found to be consistent with known safety profile with everolimus.
E.Grande RADIANT-4 Discussion
commented on the RADIANT-4 data showing a very good picture and comparing the key data from PROMID, SWOG S0518, RADIANT-2 RADIANT-4 and concluded that, while everolimus is the first drug to show in a randomized trial to have significant activity in lung NET, we do not have the full picture yet. We still have to clarify the following key issues:
  • There is no biomarker/ no molecular selection of patients
  • Low radiographic response, which is a recurrent problem when assessing clinical outcome in NETs
  • It’s unclear what should be used with patients presenting with functioning tumors or lower tumor burden/ good prognosis by primary tumor origin
  • When should everolimus be used? ‘Unknown’ line of treatment
    • E. Grande was questioning if everolimus should be pushed after SSA failure and if so whether single agent everolimus would be better than maintenance of SSA + adding on everolimus
    • To add on this key issue, we would like to highlight here the messaging that came from the Novartis symposium on Friday 25th and a poster presented on Monday 28th. In both instances everolimus was recommended in advanced NETs prior to PRRT and chemotherapy, hinting better efficacy and safety if used in earlier treatment settings (see data below)
(Left picture: Dr. Riechelmann, Novartis Symposium – for complete commentary see Novartis commentary; Right: poster n.273 - for complete commentary see Novartis commentary)
How will this new evidence presented at ECC impact on Somatuline?
During the last Global Somatuline Forum (September 18th), the Global Business Intelligence team together with the ENDO Franchise presented the potential impact of everolimus on Somatuline ahead of ECC (see picture below).
After the data presentation and various ECC activities (posters, symposium, primary intelligence) we can now formulate better possible strategies to be considered and confirmed:
  1. It’s very likely that NVS will try to bundle the promotion of Afinitor with Sandostatin LAR – at the NVS booth the two drugs were already promoted alongside (see Traction comment on NVS activities at ECC)
  2. Most likely everolimus will be positioned in earlier settings of the NET patient journey (especially in lung NET) but still after SSA
  3. We need to further evaluate the role of everolimus in symptom control (see further comments on the prIME oncology/Novartis symposium)

item.title: Phase 3 Study of Intravesical Apaziquone (EOquin®) as a Surgical Adjuvant in the Immediate Postoperative Period in Patients Undergoing TURBT
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: clinicaltrials.gov is listing a new Ph3 sponsored by Spectrum, which PE will measure time to recurrence.
Trial Details
Ref: NCT02563561
Recruitment: 1869
  • Patient must have a diagnosis with urothelial carcinoma of the bladder with clinically apparent tumor Ta, G1-G2.
  • Patient will have ≤4 tumors, none of which exceeds 3.5 cm in diameter.
  • Patient must be willing to give written informed consent and must be able to adhere to dosing and visit schedules, and meet all study requirements.
  • Patient is at least 18 years of age at randomization.
  • Patient must be willing to practice two forms of contraception, one of which must be a barrier method, from study entry until at least 35 days after the last dose of the study drug.
  • Females of childbearing potential must have a negative pregnancy test within 30 days prior to randomization. Females who are postmenopausal for at least 1 year (defined as more than 12 months since last menses) or are surgically sterilized do not require this test
Timelines: from Sept 2015 to Nov 2020 : March 2021
Location:

item.title: Photocure and KARL STORZ to Start Comparative Trial in the U.S for Diagnosis of Bladder Cancer
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: This is a prospective, open, comparative, within patient controlled multicenter trial of blue light cystoscopy with Cysview and white Light cystoscopy using KARL STORZ D-Light C PDD Flexible Videoscope System in detection of bladder cancer in patients with bladder cancer. PE will measure the proportion of patients with histologically confirmed malignancy where malignancy is only detected with blue light cystoscopy with Cysview and not white light cystoscopy.
Trial Design
Ref NCT02560584
Recruitment: approx. 360
  • Patients with bladder cancer in follow-up for tumor recurrence (Note: Patients should be included at the first surveillance cystoscopy after Transurethral Resection of the Bladder (TURB))
  • History of multiple or recurrent tumors
  • Age 18 or older
Timelines: from Sept2015 to Nov/Dec 2016

item.title: NETTER-1 Data At ESMO - Key Takeaways
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment:As anticipated, AAA released its phIII data from the NETTER-1 study at a Presidential Symposium at ESMO last Sunday. The trial which prospectively evaluated the PRRT drug Lutathera demonstrated a signficant increase in PFS compared to octreotide in patients with progressive advanced midgut neuroendocrine tumours. After a median of 30-months follow-up of 229 patients, treatment with Lutatha resulted in a 79.1% risk reduction in disease progression (p<0.001) with the median PFS not reached with Lutathera versus 8.4 months with octreotide (HR=0.209). AAA we believe will file before the year-end or early next year for approval in combination with SSA therapy for the treatment of mid-gut carcinoids.
NETTER-1 Data
The NETTER-1 study was undertaken in 51 centres in 10 countries across the world. 75% of patients had ileal tumours and almost all had liver metastases with some being lymph node positive. The strong performance of Lutathera (peptide radionuclide receptor therapy with Lu-177 Dotatate) in the study endorses data previously reported from a number of uncontrolled trials undertaken in greater than 1000 patients. The slides below from Professor P Ruzniewski's (France) presentation and those included in the subsequent discussion by Professor E Grande (Spain) are highlighted below and illustrate both the study's key findings and some points of caution raised regarding the need for the further long-term safety assessment of Lutathera to trully characterise the product in particular the long-term incidience of pancytopenia.
Professor Ruzniewski in his presentation made reference to Lutathera as representing "a major advance in treatment for the progressive mid-gut carcnoid population" whilst Professor Grande suggested that "PRRT is here to stay with the NETTER-1 data the most impressive data seen so far in the NET field."
Professor E Grande's Discussion Of the Netter-1 Data
Ipsen's Messaging Regarding Lutathera At The Global Somatuline Forum (GSF)
Whilst not speculating on the magnitude of the Lutathera response most of the points mentioned at the GSF retain their relevance.
Intelligence does suggest that AAA will submit for and potentially gain label for use in combination with SSAs not specifically octreotide. However, payers or national guidelines may still make reference to octreotide given the design of the NETTER-1 study. From a timing perspective, Ipsen's PRELUDE study should provide data on PRRT usage with lanreotide broadly coinciding with the approval of Lutathera.
As mentioned, establishing a good long-term safety profile is something AAA will need to focus upon to gain full acceptance of its product. There are also some practicalities and logistics that will not make the drug not so easily available for all patients e.g number and access to centres, drug cost and the duration of hospital stay plus the cost of managing the patient's radioactive waste.
Competitor's Positing Relative To AAA
Finally, we need to anticipate what Novartis will do in terms of positioning its own NET portfolio relative to that of AAA. Evidence to date suggests that together with the RADIANT-4 data it will look to try and push the usage of Lutathera therapy after everolimus usage.
Poster 2 229 focused on what should be the sequencing of these agents (see PFS outcome below) with some preliminary data suggesting a benefit of SSA/Everolimus prior to PRRT therapy.
Much of the data reviewed above will be discussed in more detail during a specific ESMO TC/Webex organised by the Franchise to be held on Tuesday 6th October.

item.title: Bayer Defeats U.S. FTC in Probiotics/Dietary Supplement Case
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Federal regulators have alleged that Bayer lacked reliable scientific evidence to support its claims re its Phillip's Colon Health (capsules containing Lactobacillus gasseri, KS-13, Bifidobacterium bifidum G9-1 and
Bifidobacterium longum MM-2). Bayer made the case that the substantiation that FTC sought went beyond Congress's intent for how dietary supplements should be regulated under Dietary Supplement Health and Education Act. Under this law, Bayer presented evidence that its claims were properly substantiated. According to a partner at the law firm representing the pharma group, "the government had been seeking to subject dietary supplements to the same gold standard for testing as prescription drugs".
Historical Background
Last year the US FTC brought a motion against Bayer for claims made in relation to Phillips' Coon Health (http://www.nutraingredients-usa.com/Manufacturers/Bayer-gratified-with-court-decision-vs-FTC)
The lawsuite filed by the U.S FTC alleged that Bayer lacked reliable scientific evidence to support its claim that its Phillip's Colon Health could 'defend against' occasional constipation, diarrhea, and gas and bloating, and its implied claim that the product cure those conditions.
About Phillips Colon Health
Phillips' products offer probiotic chewables and capsules for digestive health, fiber supplements, laxatives (such as milk of magnesia), stool softener (liquid gel capsules containing docusate sodium).
Phillips' Colon Health is formulated with 3 types of probiotics that help defend against occasional symptoms such as constipation, diarrhea, gas and bloating (https://www.phillipsrelief.com/products/colon-health-probiotic-caps/)
Source; Bayer; ThomsonOne; U.S. v. Bayer Corp, U.S. District Court, District of New Jersey, No. 07-00001.

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Revance's Injectable BTX-A Enters Phase 2 for Cervical Dystonia (CD)
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: This news comes after two other strategic announcements in the month of September. Revance has reported that the Ph2 study will evaluate safety, preliminary efficacy, and duration of effect of RT002 for injection in patients with moderate-to-severe isolated cervical dystonia symptoms of the neck.Interim results are expected in 2016.
Phase 2 Details
Design: open-label, sequential, dose-escalating study.
Objectives: to evaluate the safety, preliminary efficacy and duration of effect of a single treatment of RT002 (RTT150 (Botulinum Toxin Type A) for Injection) for isolated cervical dystonia.
Recruitment: Approximately 36 patients with at least moderate cervical dystonia.
Location: multiple sites in the United States.
Protocol/Dosage: There will be three treatment groups of approximately 12 patients each who will be treated with one of three doses of RT002 for injection.
The primary efficacy endpoint of the study is an improvement in dystonia symptoms as measured by change (reduction) from baseline in TWSTRS (Toronto Western Spasmodic Torticollis Rating Scale) total score at four weeks. TWSTRS is a composite scale that covers different features of the cervical dystonia condition. The first part of the scale is based on the physical findings and severity of dystonia, the second part rates the patient’s perceived level of disability, and the third part rates the pain.
Numerous secondary efficacy endpoints will be measured, including duration of effect and patient-rated quality of life as measured by change from baseline in CDIP (Cervical Dystonia Impact Profile).All patients will be followed out to nine weeks post-injection. Patients with sustained improvement after this initial period of nine weeks will continue to be assessed for duration of efficacy and other measures until they return to baseline or for up to a total of 24 weeks after treatment.
Source: Revance

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Osmotica Pharm. Gains FDA Acceptance For Ontinua ER to Treat Spasticity in Multiple Sclerosis
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Osmotica NDA for OntinuaTM extended-release tablets (arbaclofen), used in the treatment for spasticity in MS, has recently been accepted by the FDA. In addition, another key product of Osmotica, Osmolex, has progressed to phase III
Mark Stacy, MD, Vice Dean for Clinical Research, Duke University School of Medicine and head of the Osmotica’s Scientific Advisory Board reported “Using our proprietary OsmodexTM technology, we have developed OntinuaTM ER, a tablet that is intended to treat spasticity in patients with Multiple Sclerosis” “OntinuaTM ER given twice a day was shown to meet the co-primary endpoints of the Modified Ashworth Scale and the Clinical Global Impression of Change in the clinical study. “OntinuaTM ER represents a great treatment option for MS patients with spasticity, and we look forward to bringing this therapy to patients.”
Praveen Tyle, PhD, President and CEO of Osmotica Pharmaceutical Corp highlighted “Using our proprietary OsmodexTM technology, we have developed OntinuaTM ER, a tablet that is intended to treat spasticity in patients with Multiple Sclerosis. We believe this product represents an innovative option for clinicians and physicians and we look forward to bringing this therapy to our patients upon regulatory approval.”
Osmotica other key product, OsmolexTM ER, is a once-a-day, drug formulation of Amantadine HCI Extended Release Tablets also developed with Osmotica’s patented OsmodexTM technology. It is indicated for the treatment of levodopa induced dyskinesia for patients with Parkinson’s disease. OsmolexTM ER was granted orphan exclusivity in July 2015 and currently has a clinical trial program, including two phase 3 trials evaluating two doses (240mg and 320mg) in 324 aggregate patients. Osmotica intends to file a NDA in 2016
Osmotica Pharmaceutical is focused on drug delivery technologies with a special focus in neurology-based therapies. Osmotica is an international group of companies with principal operations located in the United States, Argentina and Hungary.
Source : Osmotica’s website at www.osmotica.com.

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Key Messages from Meeting with Synergy Pharm. Senior Management and Investors
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The report from BTIG outlines that plecanatide could become a meaningful new treatment with annual sales potential of approx $600M within 5 years post launch. Synergy's management highlighted the drug's potential sources of differentiation, its unique MoA and a better tolerability profile vs. Linzess and Amitiza. With approx $160M of cash, the company is adequately funded to complete the clinical development through NDA submission (for CIC and IBS-C).
Ph2b Results in IBS-C Show Promise
Synergy is currently evaluating once a day oral plecanatide at 3 mg and 6 mg doses vs. placebo for IBS-C (constipation-predominant IBS) in two large patient Phase 3 trials (combined n ~2,100).
The primary study endpoints will be the aforementioned Overall Responder. Interim data from the first study is expected by early 2016, with additional top-line data from the second study expected by mid-2016.
Pending favorable trial results, the company is targeting an NDA filing for IBS-C in 4Q16.
Top-Line Results from 2 Ph3 in CIC
Meaningful efficacy (20% patient response rate vs 10% with placebo) with a low incidence of diarrhea side effect (~3-5%). Based on these positive Phase 3 results, Synergy is targeting a January 2016 NDA submission, with an FDA approval in 2017E
Side effect comparison
Compared with Amitiza and LINZESS, plecanatide demonstrates meaningfully lower rates of diarrhea. 
  • In registrational trials for CIC and IBS-C, 16-20% of LINZESS patients experienced diarrhea, vs. 3%-6% for plecanatide 3 mg and 6 mg. 
  • In addition to diarrhea, a significant number of patients taking Amitiza reported nausea (8%-29%) and headaches (11% at 24 mcg b.id for CIC).
Source: BTIG September 29 Report

item.title: Takeda's 24-Week 22.5mg Leuplin® PRO Approved For Prostate And Premenopausal Breast Cancer In Japan
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Takeda submitted New Drug Application for 6 month formulation of its leuprorelin on Sept 2014. On 28th Sept 2015, Takeda announced that its Leuplin® PRO for injection kit 22.5mg (s.c) is approved in Japan for prostate and premenopausal breast cancer. This is its 6 month formulation of leuprorelin acetate. This is the first approval of 24 week depot leuprorelin for the treatment of premenopausal breast cancer.
This approval is based on the results of two clinical ph3 comparative study.
Leuplin was initially launched as a once daily administration by injection and Takeda has applied multiple innovations to turn it into a sustained release microcapsule depot formulation, enabling to maintain stable blood concentration levels over a long period of time. At present both 1 month and 3 month formulations have been approved and are marketed in Japan. The 6 month depot have already been available in US, EU and some countries in Asia.
Source: Takeda Press Release 28 Sept 2015

Comments
Comment: Takeda announced that its Leuplin PRO for injection kit 22.5mg is launched in Japan for Prostate and Premenopausal breast cancer with a price of ¥ 105,039.

Overview of the 24-week depot formulation

Brand name Leuplin® PRO for Injection Kit 22.5 mg
Generic name Leuprorelin acetate
Indications Prostate cancer
Premenopausal breast cancer
Dosage and administration Usually, for adults, 22.5 mg of Leuprorelin Acetate is subcutaneously administered once every 24 weeks.
When using Leuplin® PRO, it should be used after suspending it completely by transferring the whole quantity of the vehicle into the powder part, by pressing the plunger rod, with the injection needle held upward, with caution against foaming.
Drug price ¥ 105,039
Source Takeda Press Release 15 Dec 2015

item.title: Generex Starts Buccal Leuprolide R&D Work for Endocrine Disorders
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Generex recently announced a Memorandum of Understanding with NHTherapeutics, Inc. pursuant to which they will co-develop a formulation for the delivery of Leuprolide via the buccal mucosa using the Generex proprietary RapidMist™ buccal drug delivery platform technologies. The companies' initial goal is to develop the product in the 'field of endocrine disorders', such as hypogonadism.
Generex Technology
The Generex proprietary RapidMist™ drug delivery platform technology administers active pharmaceutical ingredient via aerosolized metered dose spray into the mouth for rapid absorption by the buccal mucosa.
Generex has received from NHTherapeutics the first tranche of funding as well as the initial shipment of Leuprolide.
The Generex RapidMist™ R&D protocols have been initiated, the goal of which is to achieve a formulation for the safe, simple, rapid, dose-specific, and effective administration of the active pharmaceutical ingredient into the human body via the buccal mucosa, after which local irritation and stability testing will be undertaken.
Upon successful completion of the R&D work, Generex will grant to NHTherapeutics a license for the global commercial exploitation of the product in the field of endocrine disorders in exchange for royalties.
About NHTherapeutics
  • incorporated in Toronto, Canada, with a subsidiary in the Netherlands.
  • clinical stage pharmaceutical company that focuses on conditions associated with decreased hormonal levels (hypogonadism) due to aging or disease. Current treatment options for hypogonadism have abuse liability issues and other safety concerns, may be difficult to administer and have limited efficacy.

item.title: re: ReNeuron Completes The Largest Placing For A Cell Therapy Company & Moves Stroke Programme Into PhII
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
ReNeuron Completes The Largest Placing For A Cell Therapy Company & Moves Stroke Programme Into PhII 
Comment ReNeuron, a leading UK based cell therapy company has raised a total of £68.4m, before expenses, through a conditional placing that will enable the Company to build on the considerable recent progress it has achieved across its therapeutic programmes. The placing will provide funding for the group's phII stroke disability and retinitis programmes through to market authorisation based on existing clinical development plans which anticipates PhII/III data available for the stroke cell therapy in 2018.  ...
£68.4mln raised in a share issue to support Clinical development is expected to fund the program until 2019. Hopefully long enough to see ReNeuron key product CTX (disability post-stroke) move into and complete pIII trials.
The clinical programmes include its CTX stem cell therapy candidate for disability caused by ischaemic stroke, currently in phase II clinical trials with data expected in the first half of 2016. Olav Hellebø, CEO of ReNeuron reported “Subject to an overall assessment of the collective data from the Phase I and Phase II studies, we are planning to submit an application to commence a controlled, pivotal Phase II/III clinical trial in chronically disabled stroke patients,” the company said.
At a recent company annual general meeting, Olav Hellebø reported that : “Our business has made great strides over the past year and we are now funded to deliver key clinical milestones across all of our therapeutic programmes over the next three years.”
Source: ReNeuron

item.title: Galderma Releases A New Range Of Facial Fillers
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Galdema have recently released a new range of facial fillers called Emmervel.
Recently reviewed by Galderma Scientist, Dr Barry Lycka (costmetic Dermatologist) and Pelle Winlof, Emmervel a dermal filler (Hyaluronic Acid) was recently introduced into the North American market. This new filler is thought to have a softer feel than others currently on the market providing a more natural look.
The product is positioned with a holistic view point; it’s backed by quality manufacturing, sound scientific research and dedicated customer service to both patients and physicians.

Source Digital Journal

item.title: Allergan Reports Continuing Operations Forecast
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Management's objectives are to provide transparency ahaead of the Q3 financial results (November 3rd). Following the sale of the generics business to Teva (transaction expected to close Q1:16), the reporting will be changing to 4 segments, namely: US Medical, US Brands, International Brands and Anda distribution. Top-lines are provided below.
Key Messages
Morgan Stanley analysts see that categorizing certain products into segments, such as Botox, remains unknown.
For the second-half of 2015, Allergan expects to report non-GAAP continuing operations as follows:
  • Revenue is expected to be greater than $8 billion
  • Adjusted earnings before interest and taxes (EBIT) are expected to be between $3.8 billion and $4.0 billion
  • Non-GAAP earnings per share (EPS) are expected to be between $6.25 and $6.65
Allergan's continuing operations forecast for the second half of 2015 includes all of the company's non-GAAP interest expense of approximately ~$750 million.
Following the close of the divestiture of the Generics business to Teva, New Allergan expects to have a powerful financial profile to drive continued long-term growth:
  • 10% branded revenue growth
  • Non-GAAP gross margins of 77% to 79% with additional long-term expansion anticipated
  • Non-GAAP SG&A as a percentage of revenue between 21-24%, declining within that range over time
  • Non-GAAP tax rate of ~15%
  • Interest expense for New Allergan will be largely dependent on capital deployment decisions following the close of the transaction
  • Commitment to investment grade ratings
Source: Allergan; Morgan Stanley

item.title: Revance Announces Initiation of Ph3 Study with RT001(Topical Gel) for LCL
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Revance has announced the dosing of patients in the pivotal study to assess the safety and efficacy of the topical drug for lateral canthal lines (or crow's feet). Information about the trial, including patient eligibility criteria, has not yet be published in clinicaltrials.gov. The company plans to release interim results in H1:16.
Design: randomized, double-blind, parallel-group, placebo-controlled study
Objectives: to evaluate the safety and efficacy of RT001, also referred to as RTT150 (Botulinum Toxin Type A) Topical Gel, for the treatment of moderate to severe lateral canthal lines.
Recruitment: A total of up to 450 adult patients will be enrolled
Location: multiple sites in the United States.
Regimen/Dosing: randomized 1:1 to a single treatment of either RT001 topical gel or placebo.
The product will be applied to lateral canthal lines on both sides of the face using Revance's proprietary applicator.
PE: The primary efficacy endpoints are composites based upon the Investigator's Global Assessment of Lateral Canthal Lines (IGA-LCL) assessment and the Patient Severity Assessment (PSA) between baseline and 28 days after treatment.
One composite endpoint includes those patients with a 2-point or greater improvement as graded by the investigator's assessment and the patient's self-assessment.
The other composite endpoint includes those patients who experience a 1-point or greater improvement in the investigator's and patient's assessments. Patients will also be assessed at Day 28 for muscle paralysis (or paralytic effect) using electromyography (EMG).
Source: Revance

item.title: re: Nestlé Health Science Licences Rights to Lipid Therapeutics' Novel UC Therapy
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Thanks Brigitte, So if I understand well, this would not be a substitute to mesalazine, but would be ued in case mesalazine alone is not enough. So it is still consistent with the "step-up approach" used in this disease management, and depending on results, this might delay the start of tnf-alpha inhibitors in the patient treatment pathway. Definetely an interesting topic to follow for the long-term competitive environement of Etiasa in China. 
Ferring recently launched CORTIMENT MMX in EU; the company is the licensee in Asia (excluding Japan), Australia, Canada, Latin America and Africa). The product is indicated “ … where 5-ASA treatment is not sufficient”. With Pentasa and Cortiment MMX Ferring is likely to be seen as a partner of choice for the treatment of UC products. In terms of competition with Etiasa, interesting to monitor if the company plans to seek registration for the product in China, and look to market itself or with a partner ?

item.title: re: First Analysis Demonstrates Synthetic's SYN-004's Ability to Protect the Microbiome from Damage Caused by IV Antibiotics
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
First Analysis Demonstrates Synthetic's SYN-004's Ability to Protect the Microbiome from Damage Caused by IV Antibiotics 
Comment: The data of a pilot study of humanized pigs were presented in a late-breaker oral presentation at the 2015 Interscience Conference of Antimicrobial Agents and Chemotherapy and International Congress of Chemotherapy and Infection joint meeting (ICAAC/ICC 2015) in San Diego, CA. They show that SYN-004 protected the gut microbiome from damage often caused by the intravenous (IV) beta-lactam antibiotic, ceftriaxone.  ...
Synthetic Biologis has reported the initiation of its SYN-004 Phase 2b proof-of-concept clinical trial, to evaluate the effectiveness of SYN-004the molecule to prevent C. difficile infection (CDI), C. difficile associated diarrhea (CDAD) and antibiotic-associated diarrhea (AAD) in patients hospitalized for a lower respiratory tract infection and receiving intravenous (IV) ceftriaxone.
Trial Design
The Ph2b, parallel-group, double-blind, placebo-controlled study of SYN-004 is expected to enroll approximately 370 patients at up to 75 global clinical sites.
Patients age 50 years and older, hospitalized for a lower respiratory tract infection, are expected to be randomized 1:1 into two groups, and receive either SYN-004 or placebo during the standard of care regimen of ceftriaxone (with or without a macrolide).
The primary objectives of this clinical trial are to evaluate the effectiveness of SYN-004 to prevent CDIs and CDAD.
The secondary objective of this clinical trial is to evaluate the effectiveness of SYN-004 to prevent AAD.
Source: Company's website

item.title: Chr Hansen Highlights Effect of its Probiotic Strain BB-12® in Constipation
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Chr Hansen has released on its website the results from a study, published in British Journal of Nutrition, which show that the odds for having more regular bowel movements were significantly higher when consuming the BB-12® probiotic strain for 4 weeks, compared to the placebo group. It is reported that these findings show a clinically relevant effect of the probiotic strain on bowel regulariyt. According to the company, this study which recruited 1248 subjects( varying in age from 18 to 70) has resulted in the largest dataset available on the effect of probiotics on bowel function.
About the Results

Eskesen et al. - Effect of the probiotic strain Bifidobacterium animalis subsp. lactis, BB-12® on defecation frequency in healthy subjects with low defecation frequency and abdominal discomfort: a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled, parallel-group trial - E-published ahead of print online September 21 of 2015 in British Journal of Nutrition

Abstract

The aim of the present study was to investigate the effect of Bifidobacterium animalis subsp. lactis, BB-12®, on two primary end points – defecation frequency and gastrointestinal (GI) well-being – in healthy adults with low defecation frequency and abdominal discomfort. A total of 1248 subjects were included in a randomised, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial. After a 2-week run-in period, subjects were randomised to 1 or 10 billion colony-forming units/d of the probiotic strain BB-12® or a matching placebo capsule once daily for 4 weeks. Subjects completed a diary on bowel habits, relief of abdominal discomfort and symptoms. GI well-being, defined as global relief of abdominal discomfort, did not show significant differences. The OR for having a defecation frequency above baseline for ≥50 % of the time was 1·31 (95 % CI 0·98, 1·75), P=0·071, for probiotic treatment overall. Tightening the criteria for being a responder to an increase of ≥1 d/week for ≥50 % of the time resulted in an OR of 1·55 (95 % CI 1·22, 1·96), P=0·0003, for treatment overall. A treatment effect on average defecation frequency was found (P=0·0065), with the frequency being significantly higher compared with placebo at all weeks for probiotic treatment overall (all P<0·05). Effects on defecation frequency were similar for the two doses tested, suggesting that a ceiling effect was reached with the one billion dose. Overall, 4 weeks’ supplementation with the probiotic strain BB-12® resulted in a clinically relevant benefit on defecation frequency. The results suggest that consumption of BB-12® improves the GI health of individuals whose symptoms are not sufficiently severe to consult a doctor (ISRCTN18128385). http://journals.cambridge.org/action/displayAbstract?fromPage=online&aid=9963226.

Source: http://www.chr-hansen.com/news-media/singlenews/one-of-the-worlds-largest-clinical-studies-on-probiotics-reinforces-gastrointestinal-benefits-of-th.html

item.dc:creator: spoon

Comment: Gotox is a new mobile app that was developed in response to the needs of >10 million people getting Botox® and dermal fillers in the US. It is now available for 1.99$ exclusively on the Apple App store.
Record: enter treatments and sepcify by product type, auqntities used and practitioner information
Track: archive treatment summaries for future experience and automatically be reminded when your next treatment is due
Visualize: set before and after selfies

item.title: Pfizer to be the Only Company with Two Targeted RCC Drugs in China
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Pfizer has officially launched RCC treatment Inlyta (axitinib) during the Urological Association of Asian and Chinese Urological Association (UAA/CUA) 2015 conference, convened in Shanghai last week. Inlyta joins the company's already-approved Sutent (sunitinib).
Inlyta was approved by the CFDA in May, 2015, as a treatment for RCC in adult patients after failure of a prior therapy.
  • The CFDA filing was based on the international Phase III study AXIS, and clinical data collected from a multi-center trial carried out in the Asia region, which demonstrated significant extension of progression-free survival (PFS) in comparison with Bayer's Nexavar (sorafenib).
The drug is also being developed as a therapy for hepatocellular carcinoma, as an adjuvant treatment in combination with transarterial chemoembolization (TACE), with positive Phase II results reported at this year's American Society for Clinical Oncologists (ASCO).
Source: GBI

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: BOTOX Assessed in the Treatment of Head Essential Tremor (HT)
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: In collaboration with Allergan, the University Hospital, Clermon Ferrand will be conducting a trial in 13 centers in France to demonstrate the efficacy of BOTOX ® 200 U injections in essential HT. The PE of the multi-center, randomized, double-blind, parallel-group, placebo-controlled study will measure clinical state improvement of patients evaluated by the Clinical Global Impression of Change (CGI).
REF: NCT02555982
Recruitment: approx. 120
  • Patients suffering from a head tremor without (isolated) or with associated
  • tremor in any other body parts.
  • The HT must be troublesome for the patients (TRS 2 for the head tremor
  • severity item).
  • Patients never treated with botulinum toxin.
  • Men or women aged from 18 to 80 years old.
  • Social security coverage.
Timelines: from Sept 2015 to July / Dec 2017
Locations: Clermont-Ferrand, Paris (Fondation Rothschild et APHP), Toulouse, Lyon, Amiens, Bordeaux, Narbonne, Lille, Strasbourg, Nîmes, Marseille, Besançon.

item.title: Delayed Release (DR) Formulations of Linaclotide to Enter POC for IBS-C
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Clinicaltrials.gov is listing a new trial which purpose is to to evaluate the safety, efficacy, and dose response of two delayed release formulations of linaclotide to patients IBS-C. Additional objectives include understanding how the two DR formulations compare with each other and with the FDA-approved 290 μg LINZESS® (the immediate release formulation of linaclotide). PE will measure pain and CSBM.
REF: NCT02559206
Recruitment: approx. 520
  • Patient has completed a colonoscopy according to the AGA criteria, with no clinically significant findings
  • Patient has no clinically significant findings on a physical examination and clinical laboratory tests
  • Patient meets protocol criteria for diagnosis of IBS-C
  • Patient demonstrates continued IBS-C through Pretreatment Period
  • Patient maintains a minimum level of compliance with daily diary
Timelines: from October 2015 to November 2016
Location: USA

item.title: POC of Linaclotide for IBS-C and Functional Constipation (FC) in Ped Setting to Start Next Month
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: As reported during Ironwood Q2 results , the 2 studies will be starting next month. The purpose of IBS-C study is to evaluate the safety and efficacy of linaclotide for IBS-C, in children age 7-17 years. The objective of the constipation study is to evaluate the safety and efficacy of linaclotide for FC, in children age 6-17 years. Both studies will have the same PE (change from baseline in 4-week overall spontaneous bowel movement (SBM) frequency rate (SBMs/week) during the treatment period. Those trial are part of Ironwood and Allergan continuous evaluation of the drug to strengthen the franchise.
ID: NCT02559817
REF: LIN-MD-63
Timelines: from October 2015 to April 2018
Recruitment: approx. 260
Location: North America (38 sites)
ID: NCT02559570
REF: LIN-MD-62
Timelines: from October 2015 to June 2017
Recruitment: approx 160
Location: North America (48 sites)

item.title: Guerbet Partners with Chinese Group Kuyan to Market Contrast Medium for HCC
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Lipiodol Ultra-Fluid (LUF), a contrast medium for the diagnosis and treatment of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC), is used by hepatic intra-arterial infusion. In China, first recorded therapy for HCC is TACE, followed by resection and percutaneous ethanol injection/radiofrequency ablation. TACE is recommended for Child-Pugh A/B HCC patients by the Chinese Guidelines on the diagnosis and treatment of primary liver cancer. To be noted, last year Sirtex and Guerbet initiated a collaboration in clinical studies of primary and secondary metastatic liver cancer to address the unmet clinical need in patients with HCC, metastatic CRC, metastic NET and different types of primary and secondary liver cancers. The goal of the collaboration is to examine how the SIR-Spheres microspheres of Sirtex and Lipiodol Guerbet can be combined or sequenced optimally.
Guerbet / Sirtex Agreement: See Endocrinology7634: Sirtex & Guerbet To Co-Develop Their Interventional Radiology Products For Metastatic Liver Cancer.
This agreement enables Guerbet flagship Interventional Radiology agent to benefit from Kyuan’s outstanding experience in distributing pharmaceuticals on the hospital market..

Beijing Kyuan Pharm Shortcut

One of the leading importers and distributors of medicines in China.
It was created in 1995.
Since 2001, the group has been part of Group Shanghai Pharma, the second-largest pharmaceuticals distributor in China.

Lipiodol Ultra-Fluid (LUF)

diagnostic radiology in indications including liver lesion diagnosis, lymphography andhysterosalpingography, and then used in interventional radiology for conventional transarterial chemoembolization (cTACE) procedures of multinodular hepatocellular carcinoma, where Lipiodol was used as a procedure visualizer (contrast agent), a drug eluting vehicle (drug carrier), and a dual arterio-portal transient embolic.

Lipiodol has already been approved in China for iodine insufficiency and lymphography.

Source: Guerbet


Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Exelixis Announces Three High-level Appointments
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: As Exelixis prepares for the potential commercialization of cabozantinib ( for RCC), the company has announced three high-level appointments: William Berg, M.D. as Senior Vice President of Medical Affairs, Jonathan Berndt as Vice President of Sales, and Gregg Bernier as Vice President of Marketing.The company prepares U.S. and EU regulatory filings for cabozantinib in advanced RCC, and awaits a U.S. regulatory decision on its partner Genentech's application for cobimetinib.
Drug Status
Planned U.S. and EU regulatory filings for cabozantinib in advanced renal cell carcinoma in late 2015 and early 2016.
Mini Bio
William Berg, M.D. will oversee medical affairs in the United States. He joins Exelixis after spending more than 12 years at Novartis, where he served in roles of increasing responsibility, including vice president and franchise head within Global Medical Affairs. Notably, Dr. Berg led the Afinitor® Medical Affairs program which was instrumental in the development of Afinitor® in advanced RCC. Prior to Novartis, he was a director of U.S. medical affairs at Aventis Oncology. Before entering the pharmaceutical industry.
Jonathan Berndt will lead all sales activities for cabozantinib and also direct U.S. co-promotion efforts for cobimetinib, including Exelixisâ€™ plans to field up to 25 percent of the cobimetinib U.S. sales force in the event of a potential regulatory approval later this year. Mr. Berndt joins Exelixis with two decades of commercial sales experience in the biopharmaceutical industry, including multiple oncology product and line extension launches. Most recently, he served as senior director, oncology sales at Gilead Sciences, where he assembled and led the company™s oncology sales team supporting Zydelig®. Prior to Gilead, Mr. Berndt served at Genentech for 13 years. While there, he served in a variety of roles, including directing national and regional sales for products including Rituxan® and Avastin®, and managing sales operations for Herceptin® and Tarceva®.
Gregg Bernier will lead the marketing group in its commercialization of cabozantinib for RCC. Mr. Bernier has more than 20 years of experience in biotech and pharmaceutical sales and marketing, primarily in oncology. Prior to joining Exelixis, he served as senior director of marketing at Medivation, where he led the launch of Xtandi® for a new indication in metastatic castration-resistant prostate cancer. Mr. Bernier joined Medivation from Genentech, where he worked on a variety of product launches including Tarceva®, Kadcyla®, Erivedge® and Avastin®, among other products. He has also held positions at Pharmacia and Sanofi. Mr. Bernier received his Bachelor of Arts in advertising at Michigan State University.

item.title: Merz Xeomin Is Now Registered In Australia For Multiple Therapeutic Indications Including Spasticity
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Xeomin is now registered in Australia for Blepharospasm, Cervical Dystonia, Muscle hyerptonia and AUL. Initially expected to be for the private market, Merz have registered for both private and public settings.
Merz was accepted on the PBS in April of this year but is expected to launch in September. They have commercially positioned themselves with the key selling points of
- No fridge
- Pure protein
- Large doses with dosing flexibility
Its thought to be priced the same as Dysport on the PBS but the private price remains unknown.
Source : Thomson Reuters and Ipsen Internal source
