item.title: Allergan Presents The Vistion Of The ‘New Allergan’ At The Morgan Stanely Conference
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Brent Saunders and William Meury represented Allergan at the recent Morgan Stanely conference highlighting the two key visions for the ‘new’ Allergan; development of an extensive portfolio in key therapeutic areas and maintaining a position of leadership
Brent Saunders began his presentation by highlighting the continued strong performance of Allergan in its 3rd quarter. This includes the near completion (early October) of the acquisition of Kythera with its product Kybella. With the core generics business sold, the new Allergan with its branded pharmaceutical business is confirmed to be committed to producing top line double-digit growth , an improved and increased gross margin profile in the aim to become the most efficient pharmaceutical company with respect to SG&A (as a percent of sales) while remaining to be committed to R&D.
William J Meury the executive President of Branded Pharma highlighted the two key distinguishing components for the new Allergan; first a deep product line while showing category leadership. The new vision is to provide a portfolio of products for each key therapeutic area (eye care, CNS, gastroenterology, women's health, anti-infectives and urology). This is seen to be advantageous from both a strategic perspective but also promotional; greater access to providers and payers, and economic; providing a portfolio createsa means of efficiency “The incremental cost associated with the second, third, fourth, and fifth product is much smaller and a fraction of what the cost of the first one is”. As such, across the major therapeutic areas it’s thought that the new Allergan can give customers “A more complete view of pharmacotherapy than other companies can”.
The second key area is leadership. The new Allergan is considered now to be ‘more relevant in the market with its new offering “We're number one or two in, I believe, five out of the seven product lines, which I think is a competitive advantage. The growth rates on all of our major businesses are at or above expectations; the growth is being powered more by volume than by price, which is ultimately the true measure of the health of a business”
Contary to Actavis position on R&D, the new Allergan has continued to finance R&D and remains to support this part of the business with 10% of sales invested (consistent with industry norms). The investment is considered by William to be calculated “We're not allergic to R&D. We're allergic to wasting money. And so, we take a very practical view of it. We'll invest heavily” With over 70 products in mid to late stage programs the pipeline is strong. Further discussion about the future R&D outlook will be discussed at the Allergan R&D Day on November the 4th.
With this in mind, the new Allergan outlook will be about maintaining a strong leadership position across key therapeutic areas by providing payers, physicians and patients a portfolio of products thus being more efficient in their offering. The shift from just being about sales to now a volume’s game and being a ‘one stop shop’ provider, will allow Allergan to reach the goal of increasing margin. They will continue to support R&D and also invest in M&A so to expand this portfolio and maintain or gain a leadership position across all therapeutic areas
Source: Allergan

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: 1st Prostpective Comparative Trial of Ga-68 PSMA PET Detects More Early Prostate Cancer Recurrence Than F18
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The SNNMI in its latest press release has chosen to highlight the significantly better results obtained with Ga-68 PSMA imaging compared to F18 in detecting early recurrent prostate cancer. Ga-68 PSMA in a 39 patient study changed treatment management in 44% more cases than F18.
Joshua James Morigi, MD, lead author of the study noted that the trial specifically addressed men with prostate cancer and low PSA levels, at which current imaging techniques struggle in detecting disease.
The researchers, of St. Vincent’s Hospital, Sydney, Australia, evaluated 39 prostate cancer patients who had rising PSA following first-round treatment and were eligible for further targeted therapy. Patients on systemic treatment were excluded. Ga-68 PSMA PET/CT, F-18 FMC PET/CT and diagnostic CT were undertaken in all patients sequentially between January and April 2015 and assessed by masked, experienced nuclear medicine physicians. Researchers then documented scan results and management impact changes, together with histological follow-up, if feasible. Of the patients enrolled, 89 percent had only their prostate gland removed, while the other 11 percent were post-radiation treatment.
Commenting on the studies findings Morigi stated
“Our main finding is that even at extremely low PSA levels (<0.5), PSMA was able to detect sites of possible recurrence in 50% of patients while FMC detected possible recurrence in only 12.5%. As a result of these high detection rates, PSMA also demonstrated a very high management impact in our patient cohort (63%), having an added value over FMC in 44%.”
He continued. “These findings have important ramifications for the management of men with early biochemical failure and suggest that imaging-guided therapy even in low PSA range may be possible.”
Source:- http://www.snmmi.org/NewsPublications/NewsDetail.aspx?ItemNumber=14685

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Nestlé New Push in the Health Arena
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Nestlé reported today it is building a factory in Brazil to make skin healthcare products. The company's Skin Health division has ramped up activity since its creation in February 2014 through the $3.6 billion acquisition of Galderma.
About the Plant
Objectives: 16,000-square-metre Brazilian skin health plant would help meet rising domestic and South American demand.
Products: The planned Hortolandia, Sao Paolo-based factory will produce brands for Galderma ranging from over-the-counter soaps and creams to topical gels and anti-fungal lacquers.

Planned to open in 2018, the site will cost 200 million real (approx $48M), and is likely to employ 300 workers.

Source: Thomson

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Key Messages from an Orphan Drug Payor Survey in the U.S
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Main outcomes from the Leerink MEDACorp Survey suggest that the reimbursement landscape remains highly favorable for commercially insured patients, and is able to absorb potential weakness caused by proposed changes to Medicare pricing. Bottom line outlines that considerably uncertain events, such as the presidential election and congressional acquiescence, must play out for Medicare law and pricing to change drastically, although the market has reacted as if adverse change is inevitable. The survey also includes highlights of the Clinton's plan.
About the Survey
MEDACorp surveyed 30 payors with over 165MM pharmacy and medical covered lives in the US on orphan drug spending and how it is managed at an organizational level.
Key Messages
It is reported that the Center for Medicare/Medicaid Services (CMS) estimates that prescription drugs comprise ~10% of the U.S. healthcare budget; this suggests that orphan drug spending still represents <1% of U.S healthcare spending.

For the payors who were able to estimate (just 63% within this enriched sample), orphan drugs remain a very small part of their budgets

Orphan Drug Spending Management is a Lower Priority than Many Other Drug Categories. The increased cost per patient of orphan drugs appears to be trumped by the prevalence of many other chronic diseases with expensive, long-term management needs
Clinical Efficacy Data Drives Reimbursement Decisions. Payors’ recognition that efficacy tops all other characteristics in driving reimbursement decisions (even therapy cost and availability of alternatives) confirms that potent therapies will be reimbursed

Among Orphan Therapeutic Categories, IVIG and Hemophilia Are Perceived As The Most Likely To Be Restricted In The Future

Clinton's Plan in a Nutshell

- Require drug manufacturers to provide rebates for Medicare enrollees that are equivalent to rebates in the
Medicaid program.
- Require payors to place a monthly limit of $250 on covered out-of-pocket Rx drug costs for individuals.
- Lower the biologic exclusivity period from 12 to 7 years (cited to save up to $5 billion for the federal
government over 10 years).
- Encourage the FDA to give prioritized, expedited review to biosimilar applications that only have one or
two competitors in the marketplace (situations where such drugs are most likely to be excessively priced).
- Allow Americans to import drugs from abroad – with careful protections for safety and quality.
- Require pharmaceutical companies that benefit from federal support to invest “a sufficient amount of their
revenue in R&D” or pay penalties that support research.
- Eliminate corporate write-offs for direct-to-consumer advertising and establish a mandatory FDA pre-clearance
procedure for DTC advertisements.
- Increase funding to the FDA’s Office of Generic Drugs to expedite the generic drug approval process.

Full report available on demand.

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Novartis Files Afinitor For GI Or Lung NET In Japan
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Ahead of the Phase III RADIANT-4 data presentation at ECC this coming week-end, Novartis has filed an application seeking an additional indication for Afinitor (everolimus) for the treatment of NET of gastrointestinal (GI) or lung origin in Japan.

Afinitor should be approved in 10-12 months + 2 months for pricing/reimbursement: expected launch in 2H 2016.

Source: Thank you to Hoel Goisbault (Project Manager, Japan) for the primary intelligence


Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: 'Novartis Access' Launches Portfolio of Affordable Medicines for Low-middle-income Countries
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: This is the first-of-its kind portfolio approach in healthcare industry. 'Novartis Access' will be launched first in Kenya, Ethiopia and Vietnam, with expansion to eventually include 30 countries. Portfolio addresses 15 patented and generic medicines for cardiovascular diseases, diabetes, respiratory illnesses and breast cancer. Treatments will be offered to governments, NGOs and other public-sector healthcare providers for $1 per treatment, per month.
'Novartis Access' Rationale
The launch of 'Novartis Access' will coincide with the United Nations Sustainable Development Summit 2015, where the new Sustainable Development ProgrGoals will be adopted.
Figures
Approx. 28M people die from chronic diseases in those countries each year, representing about 75% of such deaths globally.(source: World Health Organization, "Noncommunicable diseases fact sheet":
http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs355/en/(link is external), Accessed 14 September 2015 ).
Source: from https://www.novartis.com/news/media-releases/novartis-launches-novartis-access-portfolio-affordable-medicines-treat-chronic

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Mrs Clinton's Proposal on Cap Drug Costs Hits Lexicon Shares
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Summary: While at a forum in Iowa, Hillary Clinton responded to the voter fury rising over the high-cost of prescriptions drugs with a proposal for capping out-of-pocket drug expenses at $250 a month. The proposal also touched on establishing a set ratio between revenue and research spending, and eliminating the tax deductibility of drug marketing expenses. The Pharmaceutical Research and Manufacturers of America, which represents the country’s leading drug makers, said in a statement that Mrs Clinton’s plan would “turn back the clock on medical innovation, restrict patient's access to new medicines, resulting in fewer new treatments for patients, eroding the nation’s standing as the world leader in biomedical innovation". Her plans to reform hit the biotech stocks, Lexicon Pharmaceuticals being amongst those who have been impacted the most significantly (down 10.1%).
The investors had reacted positively to the announcement of the positive Phase III results for Telotristat etiprate for carcinoid syndrome. Telotristat etiprate has been awarded both fast-track and orphan drug status by the FDA. Those designations could allow faster market entry for Lexicon's drug, and if so, telotristat etiprate could become an important treatment option for patients who don't respond to high-price SSA, such as sandostatin LAR (that costs $2,466 for a 30mg dose). This proposal could have an impact on Lexicon’s pricing strategy and revenue ambition in the US (i.e.Lexicon can't price telotristat etiprate similarly to sandostatin LAR), and possibly lead to readjustment of analysts’ forecast for Lexicon. Hence its shares slumped yesterday.
Source: FT, New York Times

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Oncogenex Reported Non Superiority Result For Its OGX-427 In 1L Metastatic Pancreatic Cancer
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Oncogenex reported initial results from the Ph2 Rainier study that the addition of its apatorsen (OGX-427) to gemcitabine and Abraxane did not demonstrate a survival benefit compared to Abraxane + Gemcitabine alone in the first line setting. While fewer patients taking apatorsen had discontinued treatment due to the disease progressing, more patients stopped the therapy due to adverse events such as anemia, fatigue and neutropenia, an abnormally low white blood cell count Further results will be presented by Sarah Cannon Research Institute at a future medical meeting (likely to be ASCO GI in 2016).
Pancreatic cancer has been one of the very difficult-to-treat cancers as over the last decade, very few treatments have been able to demonstrate a survival benefit. Apatorsen (OGX-427) is a once-weekly intravenous (IV) experimental drug that is designed to inhibit production of heat shock protein 27 (Hsp27) to disable cancer cells' defenses and overcome treatment resistance. Hsp27 in an intracellular protein that protects cancer cells by helping them survive, leading to resistance and more aggressive cancer phenotypes. Both the potential single-agent activity and synergistic activity of apatorsen with cancer treatments may increase the overall benefit of existing therapies and augment the durability of treatment outcomes, which could lead to increased patient survival.
Source: OncoGenex Press Release 23 Sept 2015

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Nestlé Institute of Health (NIHS) Moves Forward in the Battle Against Alzheimer's Disease
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: This further initiative into the medicine business has been signed with biotech firm AC Immune to develop a Tau diagnosis assay for Alzheimer's disease. Link between nutrition and dementia has been very promising. Since 2013, NIHS has applied its proprietary multiplexed ultrasensitive triplex antidody technology in Brain Health research, specifically in this condition, and last July, it established a new 'hub' in nutrition, metabolisms and dementia to feed innovation.
Financial terms: not disclosed
Objective: to develop a sensitive, minimally invasive Tau diagnostic assay for early Alzheimer’s disease.
Two-day conference hosted by the New York Academy of Sciences and the Sackler Institute for Nutrition Science.
Sponsored by the Nestlé Nutrition Institute and Nestlé Health Science.
Focus:
  • Nutritional consequences of the aging demographic: epidemiological perspectives,
  • The role of nutrition in dementia prevention, and
  • The role of nutrition and distinct nutritional requirements in the management of dementia
  1. ScreenCapture1.jpg  (30 KB)

item.title: HCC Continues to Pose China's Greatest Health Challenge
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: As the world’s sixth most common cancer, and second most significant cause of cancer death, liver cancer can hardly be characterized as a disease exclusive to China. The report outlines a significant unmet diagnosis and treatment needs in China. Current development trends are seeing new signaling pathways (such as telomerase Wnt/beta-catenin) or combinations of pathways being targeted while drugs that target single sites are being thoroughly investigated in combination treatments. It is highlighted that the support of a local partner is a necessity as it allows access to accelerated CFDA review, and the potential for regulatory exclusivity upon approval. A selection of molecules in development for HCC in Greater China is provided below, among which about ten are in Ph3.
Global Variations in Diagnosis and Treatment
Sanofi's Eloxatin - chemo drug, marketed in 2013 for unresectable, advanced HCC.
The nationally reimbursed FOLFOX chemo-therapy regimen is included in the National Health and Family Planning Commission's treatment guideline.
The only targeted therapy for HCC to date is Bayer's Nexavar (sorafenib) approved in 2008. However resource constraints limit its use in China.
  • 2014 Nexavar sales for both RCC and HCC were RMB 165M ($26.7M), with growth at 12.24% YOY.
Source: Liver Cancer - Meeting the treatment demand for China's silent killer.

Comments
A new Ph2/3 trial has been recently listed in clinicaltrials.gov with the objective to assess efficacy and safety of donafenib in approx. 600 patients with advanced hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC). PE will measure OS. Suzhou Zelgen Biopharmaceuticals Co.,Ltd is the sponsor of the study, and the developper of donafenib, an oral multikinase inhibitor that targets Raf kinase and receptor tyrosine kinases.
Trial ID: NCT02645981
Timelines: the trial is to start in February 2016 and complete Dec 2018 / Aug 2019

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Allergan Attempts To Re-enter The Generic Space Venturing into the Parkinson's Disease Market
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Allergan confirmed yesterday a patent challenge to IMPAX's Rytary a carbidopa/levadopa extended release formulation. It has filed an ANDA with the U.S. FDA seeking approval to market a generic version of Carbidopa and Levodopa Extended-release Capsules, 61.25 mg/245 mg, 23.75 mg/95 mg, 36.25 mg/145 mg and 48.75 mg/195 mg. Rytary®, is currently indicated for the treatment of Parkinson's disease and post-encephalitic parkinsonism. The questions is whether the rational is based around market seeding for a new undisclosed drug/ lifecycle indication or commercial adjacency to the botulinum toxin market.
IMPAX's Response

Impax Laboratories, Inc. filed suit against Allergan on August 17, 2015 in the U.S. District Court for the District of New Jersey seeking to prevent Allergan from commercializing its ANDA product prior to the expiration of certain U.S. Patents.
The lawsuit was filed under the provisions of the Hatch-Waxman Act, resulting in a stay of final FDA approval of Allergan's ANDA for up to 30 months from the date the plaintiffs received notice of Allergan's ANDA filing or until final resolution of the matter before the court, whichever occurs sooner, subject to any other exclusivities.
Based on available information, Allergan believes it may be a "first applicant" to file an ANDA for the generic version of Rytary® and, should its ANDA be approved, may be entitled to 180 days of generic market exclusivity.
For the 12 months ending July 31, 2015, Rytary® had total U.S. sales of approximately $15 million, according to IMS Health data.
The Rational For Allergan's Filing
Having sold its generic business to Teva at the end of July this year, this development is somewhat surprising (see Neurology8122: Allergan Divests Generics Business To Merge With Teva As It Focuses On Becoming A Branded Pharma Leader) especially as there no evidence on ClinicalTrials.gov of any ongoing development activity in Parkinsons's disease. However, maybe there are plans afoot as Allergan's 1st entry into the urology market with botulinum toxin was preceeded by the in-licensing of an anticholinergic drug Sanctura in 2007 which had only 3 yrs of patent exclusivity left and achieved peak sales of $62m before being impacted by generics and subsequently withdrawn from the market.
Source: www.allergan.com

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Two-Drug Combination Shows Very Early Promise in pNET
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The University of Florida Health researchers have shown for the first time that the focal adhesion kinase (FAK) protein becomes overabundant in pNETs and have a key role in tumor development. They looked at drug combinations that would increase efficacy and tested a small compound molecule, PF-04554787 in human pancreatic cancer cell lines. They also paired the compound with everolimus, proving that the two-drug combination kills off one type of pancreatic cancer cells more effectively than everolimus alone. While this is a very interesting approach it's still a very long way to any clinical trials and/or every-day clinic, but offer new insights in the biology of pNETs.
FAK activates an enzyme called AKT, which helps islet cells in the pancreas to survive. When islet cells begin turning into tumors, the FAK protein gets overexpresses, allowing the tumor to resist chemotherapy and evading the efforts to kill them off. Once identified that FAK was important, the group tested a synthetic, small-molecule compound known as PF-04554787. During lab testing, the compound “markedly inhibited” the growth of three human pancreatic cancer cell lines five days after treatment and induced the death of pancreatic cancer cells. Researchers then tested its effectiveness on human pancreatic cells that had been implanted in mouse models. Daily doses of the compound reduced tumor volume by about 50 percent after 25 days, they found.
Next, researchers paired the compound with everolimus. While everolimus can extend some patients’ lives by holding tumors in check, it does little to make them regress and is not effective for many people. François wondered if the synthetic compound would make everolimus more effective. It did, with the two-drug combination killing off pancreatic cancer cells more effectively than everolimus alone. In testing on two mouse cell lines, the drug combination reduced the viability of cancer cells by about 50 percent when compared with everolimus alone, according to the findings.
Source: University of Florida Health

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: TRACON Pharm Reported To Target Two Orphan Tumours - Choriocarcinoma And Angiosarcoma
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: TRACON pharm, formerly known as Lexington Pharm, announced that its leading candidate, TRC105 demonstrated complete response in two orphan tumour types that overexperess endoglin, choriocarcinoma, and angiosarcoma. A Ph2 multi-centre trial is expected to initiate in Q4 2015 and will file application for orphan drug status by end of 2015. As a result, shares of Tracon Pharm soared 36% after the announcement.
A single-patient compassionate use phase II study
The patient was treated with TRC105 dosed 10 mg/kg weekly in combination with Avastin® (bevacizumab) dosed 10 mg/kg every other week. As of the time of the presentation, the patient had completed 7 cycles (28 weeks) of treatment. Beta human chorionic gonadotropin (β-hCG), a known, reliable marker of disease burden in choriocarcinoma, normalized during the fourth cycle of treatment, decreasing from greater than 3,000 IU/L at treatment initiation to less than 1 IU/L from cycles 4 through 7, indicating an ongoing complete response.
Choriocarcinoma represents the second tumor type known to express high levels of endoglin in which complete durable responses have been observed following treatment with a combination of TRC105 and a VEGF inhibitor. In June 2015, Dr. Steven Attia of the Mayo Clinic reported complete responses in two patients with angiosarcoma, treated with TRC105 and Votrient® (pazopanib), at the American Society of Clinical Oncology (ASCO) annual meeting in Chicago.
About Tracon
Tracon expects to commercialize TRC105 on its own in the U.S. and to partner the agent elsewhere. Theuer, who joined the company in 2006, was previously director of clinical oncology at Pfizer Inc., where he led the clinical development of Sutent (sunitinib), approved by the FDA in 2006 to treat gastrointestinal stromal tumours and advanced kidney cancer. Before that, he served in senior management at Idec Pharmaceuticals Inc., which merged with Biogen Inc. in 2003 to form the biotech powerhouse, and worked at the National Cancer Institute.
In 2014, Tracon inked a deal with Santen Pharmaceutical Co. Ltd., of Osaka, Japan, for $10 million up front and undisclosed future milestones to develop and commercialize TRC105 in age-related macular degeneration. Santen filed an investigational new drug application in that indication at the end of the second quarter. In September 2014, Tracon raised $27 million in a series B before filing paperwork for its IPO, which brought in $36 million earlier this year. Tracon reported cash and equivalents of $61.2 million as of June 30, giving the company a runway of at least 18 months, according to Casey Logan, chief business officer.
Source: TRACON Press Release

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: AstraZeneca To Harness The Scientific Prowess Of Crowds To Identify New Oncology Drug Combinations
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: AstraZeneca has taken the unprecedented step of releasing preclinical data for 50 of its preclinical oncology drugs with the aim of utilising crowd sourcing to try and identify syntergistic tumour-fighting combinations.
The initiative is being run as part of the DREAM Challenge, an open inovation non-profit biology project in which scientists pool data and crunch data. The data includes around 10,000 tested combinationns meansuring the ability of drugs to destroy cancer cell lines from different tumour types. The data will be matched with genomic information from the Wellcome Trust Sanger Insititute.
Scientists with winning predictions will have their ideas submitted for publication in Nature.
Source: www.astrazeneca.com

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: First Analysis Demonstrates Synthetic's SYN-004's Ability to Protect the Microbiome from Damage Caused by IV Antibiotics
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The data of a pilot study of humanized pigs were presented in a late-breaker oral presentation at the 2015 Interscience Conference of Antimicrobial Agents and Chemotherapy and International Congress of Chemotherapy and Infection joint meeting (ICAAC/ICC 2015) in San Diego, CA. They show that SYN-004 protected the gut microbiome from damage often caused by the intravenous (IV) beta-lactam antibiotic, ceftriaxone.
Presented by Vice President, Research, Sheila Connelly, Ph.D.,
  • Of significant importance, in the cohort that was administered oral SYN-004 plus IV ceftriaxone, the natural balance of bacteria in the gut microbiome was maintained.
  • In contrast, in the cohort administered IV ceftriaxone alone, damage occurred and the natural balance of the gut microbiome was altered.
Timelines: SYN-004 Phase 2b proof-of-concept trial expected later this quarter
From http://www.syntheticbiologics

Comments
Synthetic Biologis has reported the initiation of its SYN-004 Phase 2b proof-of-concept clinical trial, to evaluate the effectiveness of SYN-004the molecule to prevent C. difficile infection (CDI), C. difficile associated diarrhea (CDAD) and antibiotic-associated diarrhea (AAD) in patients hospitalized for a lower respiratory tract infection and receiving intravenous (IV) ceftriaxone.
Trial Design
The Ph2b, parallel-group, double-blind, placebo-controlled study of SYN-004 is expected to enroll approximately 370 patients at up to 75 global clinical sites.
Patients age 50 years and older, hospitalized for a lower respiratory tract infection, are expected to be randomized 1:1 into two groups, and receive either SYN-004 or placebo during the standard of care regimen of ceftriaxone (with or without a macrolide).
The primary objectives of this clinical trial are to evaluate the effectiveness of SYN-004 to prevent CDIs and CDAD.
The secondary objective of this clinical trial is to evaluate the effectiveness of SYN-004 to prevent AAD.
Source: Company's website
  1. ScreenCapture1.jpg  (115,8 KB)
  2. ScreenCapture2.jpg  (107,4 KB)

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Bayer Aligns Organization with Life Science Businesses
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Announced two years ago, the new strategy is now in place to align the organization with Life Science businesses. From January 1st 2016, the company's business will be managed by 3 divisions: Pharmaceuticals, Consumer Health and Crop Science.
The divisions are to focus on core competencies close to their businesses - research and development, production, and sales & marketing.
They will be supported by integrated functions such as Human Resources and Procurement, and by global services.
Effective January 1, 2016, the Board of Management of Bayer AG will comprise eight members headed by Chairman Dr. Marijn Dekkers. Johannes Dietsch will be responsible for Finance; Werner Baumann will oversee Strategy and Portfolio Management; and Kemal Malik will have responsibility for Innovation. Michael König will be leaving the company at his own request on expiration of his contract. Dr. Hartmut Klusik, currently responsible for Product Supply on the Board of Management of Bayer HealthCare AG, will be the new Labor Director and Board member responsible for Human Resources, Technology and Sustainability. As part of the reorganization, the Board of Management areas for Innovation and Technology will be additionally strengthened. The Board of Management will also be enlarged to include the three divisional heads: Dieter Weinand (headquartered in Berlin, Germany), Erica Mann (headquartered in the future in Basel, Switzerland) and Liam Condon (headquartered in Monheim, Germany).
Background in Traction Please see PharmaWorld10957: Bayer To Transform Itself Into A Pure Life Science Company
Source: http://www.press.bayer.com/baynews/baynews.nsf/id/Bayer-aligns-organization-with-Life-Science-businesses

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: re: Pfizer Announces More Committment to Vaccines
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Pfizer Announces More Committment to Vaccines 
Comment: Pfizer's strategy is definitely to expand beyond Prevnar. Today management announced enrollment of its first patients in a Ph2b trial for its Staphylococcus aureus vaccine. To be noted, in the company's pipeline is a Ph2 vaccine for the prevention Clostridium difficile. In August 2014, the vaccine got a FDA fast-track designation, a competitive advantage over Sanofi Pasteur and Merck's investigational vaccines.  ...
Merck anounced on Sept.20th that the two pivotal Ph 3 clinical studies for bezlotoxumab, for prevention of Clostridium difficile (C. difficile) infection recurrence, met their primary efficacy endpoint: the reduction in C. difficile recurrence through week 12 compared to placebo, when used in conjunction with standard of care antibiotics for the treatment of C. difficile. The studies showed no benefit from a second experimental antibody, actoxumab, either alone or in combination with bezlotoxumab. Merck said the actoxumab arm was stopped for efficacy and safety reasons after an interim analysis. Based on these results, the company plans to submit new drug applications seeking regulatory approval of bezlotoxumab in the U.S., EU and Canada in 2015.
Currently, there are no therapies approved for the prevention of recurrent disease caused by C. difficile.
Results from the studies were presented for the first time at the Interscience Conference of Antimicrobial Agents and Chemotherapy (ICAAC) and International Congress of Chemotherapy and Infection (ICC) joint meeting in San Diego, Sept. 17-21.
Source: http://www.mercknewsroom.com/news-release/research-and-development-news/pivotal-phase-3-studies-bezlotoxumab-mercks-investigation
About the pivotal Phase 3 studies
Two global, Phase 3, double-blind studies were conducted to evaluate bezlotoxumab, either alone or in combination with actoxumab (a fully human monoclonal antibody against C. difficile toxin A), compared to placebo for the prevention of recurrent C. difficile infection in patients on standard of care antibiotics for a primary or recurrent C. difficile infection.
The MODIFY I study (MONOCOLONAL ANTIBODIES FOR C. DIFFICILE THERAPY) enrolled 1452 patients (median age 65 years) in 19 countries and the MODIFY II study enrolled 1203 patients (median age 67 years) in 17 countries. The studies were conducted in both hospital and outpatient settings, and the primary endpoint for each study was evaluated through 12 weeks following study drug administration


Add a Comment on this Article

View thread GastroEnterology2463: Pfizer Announces More Committment to Vaccines

item.title: 18-Month Data of Versartis VRS-317 for PGHD
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Versartis gained $2.16 (20%) to $13.14 after reporting 18-month data from a long-term extension study of somavaratan, a long-acting recombinant human growth hormone (rhGH), in pre-pubertal children with growth hormone deficiency (GHD). Versartis said the data demonstrated a stabilization of mean height velocity, noting that patients commonly experience a decrease in height velocity during their second year on a daily rhGH treatment. Furthermore, the number of adverse events (AEs) declined between 12 and 18 months, and no serious AEs were reported. Detailed results will be presented at the European Society for Paediatric Endocrinology meeting in Barcelona on Oct. 3.
The extension study included 56 patients who received either twice-monthly 2.5 mg/kg or once-monthly 5 mg/kg doses of somavaratan for 12 months followed by twice-monthly 3.5 mg/kg doses for six months. The 3.5 mg/kg dose is currently being evaluated in the Phase III VELOCITY trial.
Patients who switched from the twice-monthly 2.5 mg/kg dose to the twice-monthly 3.5 mg/kg dose experienced an increase in mean peak insulin-like growth factor-1 (IGF-1) standard deviation score (SDS) from -0.30 to 0.32 (p=0.007).
During the first 12 months of treatment, patients in the 2.5 mg/kg dose group and 5 mg/kg dose groups experienced a mean height velocity of 8.5 cm/year and 7.9 cm/year, respectively.
After switching to the twice-monthly 3.5 mg/kg dose for an additional six months, patients demonstrated a mean annualized height velocity of 8.3 cm/year and 8.1 cm/year, respectively.
Background
Versartis resumed the VELOCITY trial in July after FDA lifted a partial clinical hold on the study. In May, FDA had suspended enrollment and requested additional bioanalytical data from the company. See Endocrinology8044: Versartis' Long-Acting PhIII Development Placed On Clinical Hold

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Novartis CEO Reports on the Slowdown in Emerging Markets
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: In an interview with CNBC, Joe Jimenez has stated that business in China is "moving from mild-double-digit growth rates to now in the mid-single-digit growth rates". Despite fears of an economic slowdown in the country, Novartis is "not pulling back from the country.
According to Jimenez, Sandoz is expected to help drive growth in China.
He also has remarked on the Federal Reserve's recent decision to maintain current interest rates, saying that while the central bank will likely lift its rates at some point, the timing is not of great importance to Novartis.
"The more interesting thing is that this is the first time that an event in China has led to global dislocation of financial markets," Jimenez explained, adding "that is a big marker that says China has arrived and it is going to have a big impact on global markets."

item.title: New Trial to Document Registry of Participants With Prostate Cancer in Asia
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The purpose of this Ph4 study, sponsored by Janssen R&D, is to document prostate cancer (PC) management including diagnosis, prognosis, treatment, and care in real-world practice. PE will measure OS, prostate cancer-related mortality, MFS, PFS, TTPP. Recruitment has been designed to enrol approx. 3730 participants with documented diagnosis of PC with either: High-risk localized PC; Non-metastatic, biochemically recurrent PC; Metastatic PC. The maximum observational period will be 5 years.
Trial Details
REF: NCT02546908
ID: CR107351, NOPRODPCR4001
Timelines completion in Sept 2020
Locations China; India; Korea; Malaysia;Singapore; Taiwan Thailand

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Drivers Behind AstraZeneca's Business In China
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Deustche Bank analysts have just published a 69-page report on strong growth prospects for AstraZeneca based on its operational success in emerging markets and strength of the pipeline. In March this year AZN set out its current strategy for a return-to-growth with the focus on driving investment behind its five current "growth platforms" i.e. Brilinta/Brilique, diabetes, respiratory, Emerging Markets and Japan. In doing this, management outlined plans to leverage its commercial infrastructure in primary care and its core specialty therapeutic areas, as well its strong position in China and emerging markets. Both the Deutsche report and Pascal Soret's (CEO) comments during AZ's Q2 webcast (CEO) highlight the key factors behind AZ's success in the Chinese market and the group's significant expansion plans to maintain growth in this region.
Key Chinese Growth Drivers
The main drugs generating strong growth in China are the group's respiratory drugs Pulmicort and Symbicort. Although Pulmicort is now generic in the US, sales in emerging markets continue to grow strongly (+44% CER in 2Q). This has been aided by AZN’s collaboration with Omron to place nebulisers in hospitals in China, where access to asthma therapies is limited.
Duetsche analysts suggest that AZN is continuing to perform above its peers in emerging markets. Its sales reached $5.8bn in 2014 (+12% 22% of total sales) and it appears to be benefiting from GSK's continued woes in China with AZ's Symbicort taking sizeable market share from GSK's Advair in the respiratory category). The company has also highlighted the statin Crestor and the GI drug Nexium as strong growth drivers in EMs.
AZ's Risk Exposure to China
With many pharmaceutical companies reporting a slowdown, Novartis as of today in a CNBC interview with CEO Joe Jimines the Deustche analysts make the following observation about AZ's risk profile:-
"AZN now has the highest concentration of EM sales in China of any of our coverage companies. In fact it is now second only to Pfizer among the multi-nationals in China, with >10% of its sales coming from the country in 1H15. However, more recently fears have been raised given several other healthcare companies suggesting that the China market appears to have shown a sharp deceleration in Q2. Eli Lilly noted on their 2Q15 call that growth for international pharma companies was 2% in May in China, having been running at mid-teens in recent years. Clearly this is a risk for AZN more than others companyies given its exposure and dependence on China for continued EM growth. However, to date its growth has remained strong, with sales still growing at 10% CER in 2Q, despite reversal of a destock that drove exceptional growth in sales in 1Q15. We note that AZN’s Chinese sales are highly concentrated on several key franchises, with Pulmicort alone representing close to 20% of its sales in the region, reflecting its investment in supporting asthma and COPD treatment in the region. Even with a slowdown in economic growth in the region, we expect improved access to healthcare to continue to represent a meaningful opportunity for the industry."
CEO's Reference To China During Q2 Webcast
During its Earnings Webcast on July 30th, Pascal Soret made the following comments about the growth outlook for its Chinese business and Emerging markets

" There was a continued strong performance in the half. After a very brisk Q1 with 18% growth overall and 28% in China, Q2 normalized to 9% growth in line with our long-term view. China sales were slower in Q2 with a growth of 10%, equating to 19% over the half year. Growth was spread across all main therapeutic areas. Respiratory was up 30% in Emerging Markets to $556 million, Brilinta up 80% to $47 million, Diabetes up 88% to $117 million, and Oncology up 18% to $483 million. Going to the second half of 2015 our expectation is to deliver continued double-digit growth in China."

"If we look at China I think it's fair to say that there is a structural slowing in the market, which I don't think is a surprise to anyone who's following the overall economy in China. That being said where our focus is, I mean clearly we have a strong position in the large Eastern provinces. But as we go to lower tier cities in the West, we have a concentrated expansion program there. Also our mix of products right now, there is a lot of volume reflex. If we look into the future again if we look at products such as Pearl and also the Oncology portfolio, again we're well placed if we look at the 5- to 10-year horizon And although this evolution in China is something that we have been expecting a long time, we have said many times, there will be price pressure. And so we are expanding in the West. And we have a very substantial expansion program to unlock growth potential in those areas that are economically developing, so we expect to maintain this."

Source: www.astrazeneca.com

item.title: Chiasma Starts Planning The Phase III for Oral Octreotide In Europe
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: We have gained some primary intelligence that confirms the Chiasma plans for conducting a Phase III study for oral octreotide in Europe for acromegaly. The study is not yet in the public domain and the intended start date is January 2016, which potentially could meet the estimated MAA planning submission to the EMA in late 2017 or early 2018. The details are listed below.
Eudract No 2015-002854-11
Sponsor Chiasma INC
Protocol Title OOC-ACM-302
Countries- European Study
Title: A phase 3, randomized, open-label, active controlled, multicenter study to evaluate maintenance of response, safety and patient reported outcomes in acromegaly patients treated with octreotide capsules, and in patients treated with standard of care parenteral somatostatin receptor ligands who previously tolerated and demonstrated a biochemical control on both treatments.
Source: UK medical affairs - Thank you!

Comments
Further to the primary intelligence, Chiasma has released a preliminary design of the planned Phase III b trial to support EMA approval (see picture). Chiasma is due to present the Q3 2015 results next week where we might learn more.
Source: Chiasma IR September 2015

item.title: Key Messages from Ironwood Management @ Morgan Stanley H/C Conference
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Management sees LINZESS (linaclotide) as the market leader, with a "broad offering to a broad set of patients". The drug has been approved and launched for IBS-C or CIC in adults since end of 2012. Management reported it is too early to see Synergy Pharm.'s plecanatide as a direct competitor, and reported that "... they certainly have data in chronic constipation. We'll have to wait and see what the IBS data looks like". When questionned on M&A, Mark Curie outlined they are looking at acquiring assets, and organizations if they bring value to the shareholders and the company. Please see below additional information.
Completed enrollment in the Ph3 in adult patients with chronic idiopathic constipation (CIC). Data from this trial are expected in the fourth quarter of 2015 and a supplemental new drug application is expected to be submitted to the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) in the first half of 2016.
If approved, the 72 mcg dose should accelerate the expansion of LINZESS use within adult CIC patients by providing physicians an additional dosing option for this large and diverse population. According to management, the lower dose has been developed for patients with mild-to-moderate disease, or for patients who tend to be more sensitive to the drug.
Completed enrollment in the Ph2. Data from this study are expected in the fourth quarter of 2015.
Management reported it is watching really closely 'how big the OIC market is', as Amitiza 'saw some modest growth" since its launch.
Indicatio/status: gastroparesis Phase 2a group of concept study.
" ... We should have data in the first half of next year and it's a very exciting opportunity and that these patients essentially have no real therapy currently and there have been multiple attempts to try to fix the mechanics of improving gastric emptying in the gastroparesis patients that haven't been successful. We're taking a very different approach, which is we are going after trying to reduce the visceral sensations that we've been so successful at previously with linaclotide in the lower GI."
Finalizing preparations for the IW-3718 dose-ranging Ph2b study, which is expected to initiate in early 2016.
" ... we went into a broad population of patients that are suffering refractory GERD and we characterized broadly their symptom response and then we look for specifically now what are the phenotype of those patients that we can horn in on that where our drug would potentially work the best.
So with 3718, we are in that process and you'll see at the ACG".
When it comes to the positoinning of the drug: " ... So this is going to be used on top of PPIs. So the base line treatment would be single or double dose PPI and if you're still suffering heart burn, this would be appropriate. There's been a number of epidemiology studies done, probably the most notable is by Bill Chey, which is about 20% to 25% of the treated GERD population, which is roughly about 8 million Americans.
And the attractive thing commercially for us is, one, these patients are easily identified, they're actively seeking care and they're very problematic for the clinician. So I think it's a great move for us. It's right in the wheelhouse in GI for us. So we're in those offices are ready. So, commercially, it's a very attractive opportunity.
As far as step edits, I think it's likely that early on there could be, but I think it could be fairly easy to walk through these -- the step edits of the prior authorization because they already got a history of treating and failing on PPIs."

item.title: AbbVie to Initiate Ph3 of Elagolix (GnRH Antagonist) for Uterine Fibroids (UF) in Q1:16
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Preliminary results from 6-month, Ph2b safety and efficacy trial show elagolix met composite PE in UF. Final results will be presented at a medical conference in the future. Elagolix Uterine Fibroid Phase 2a data have been accepted for presentation at the 2015 Annual Meeting of the American Society of Reproductive Medicine in Baltimore, October 2015. At the beginning of the year, management reported positive top-line results from the first of two ongoing Ph3 trials, designed to assess the efficacy and safety of the drug in premenopausal women with endometriosis
Ph2b Results
Preliminary results showed that all of the elagolix treatment arms, with and without add-back therapy, reduced heavy menstrual bleeding as compared to placebo (p<0.001).
The study's PE was a composite design where subjects had to achieve a menstrual blood loss (MBL) volume of less than 80 mL as well as a 50 percent or greater reduction in MBL volume from baseline at the final study month as measured by the alkaline hematin method.
Among the most common adverse events (AEs) were hot flush, headache, nausea, and vomiting. Some AEs such as hot flush were more frequent in the elagolix only treatment arms as compared to the placebo and elagolix with add-back therapy treatment arms.
Reduction in bone mineral density associated with elagolix alone was attenuated when elagolix was co-administered with add-back therapy.
Discontinuations due to AEs were slightly greater for the elagolix 600 mg once-daily (QD) treatment arms with and without add-back therapy as compared to elagolix 300mg twice-daily (BID) treatment arms with and without add-back therapy.
About the Ph3 Program
Will include two replicate, pivotal, six-month efficacy and safety studies followed by a six-month safety and efficacy extension study.
The primary endpoint in Phase 3 studies will be the same as that employed in the Phase 2b study; percent of subjects with reduction in uterine blood flow as measured by the alkaline hematin method.

item.title: re: Nestlé Health Science Licences Rights to Lipid Therapeutics' Novel UC Therapy
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Nestlé Health Science Licences Rights to Lipid Therapeutics' Novel UC Therapy 
Comment: LT-02, phosphatidylcholine, is a novel barrier function therapy for patients with mild-to-moderate ulcerative colitis (UC). Nestlé, which acquired WW rights except EU and Australia), plans to start Ph3 in the US in 2016. EU development partner, Dr Falk Pharma GmbH started the Ph3 in 2014.  ...
Thanks Brigitte, So if I understand well, this would not be a substitute to mesalazine, but would be ued in case mesalazine alone is not enough. So it is still consistent with the "step-up approach" used in this disease management, and depending on results, this might delay the start of tnf-alpha inhibitors in the patient treatment pathway. Definetely an interesting topic to follow for the long-term competitive environement of Etiasa in China.
Ferring recently launched CORTIMENT MMX in EU; the company is the licensee in Asia (excluding Japan), Australia, Canada, Latin America and Africa). The product is indicated “ … where 5-ASA treatment is not sufficient”. With Pentasa and Cortiment MMX Ferring is likely to be seen as a partner of choice for the treatment of UC products. In terms of competition with Etiasa, interesting to monitor if the company plans to seek registration for the product in China, and look to market itself or with a partner ?

item.title: Nestlé Health Science Licences Rights to Lipid Therapeutics' Novel UC Therapy
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: LT-02, phosphatidylcholine, is a novel barrier function therapy for patients with mild-to-moderate ulcerative colitis (UC). Nestlé, which acquired WW rights except EU and Australia), plans to start Ph3 in the US in 2016. EU development partner, Dr Falk Pharma GmbH started the Ph3 in 2014.
Financial terms: not disclosed
Nestlé Health Science will further develop and commercialize LT-02 upon marketing approval by the relevant authorities in the licensed geographies
As part of a strategic development approach, Nestlé Health Science, Dr Falk and Lipid Therapeutics will collaborate to generate the required clinical evidence in support of LT-02’s beneficial effects in the treatment of ulcerative colitis in order to obtain drug regulatory approvals.
LT-02 restores the colonic barrier function in the gut mucosa or ‘wall’ and through anti-inflammatory signalling and represents a first-in-class therapy for those patients still suffering flares while being treated with mesalazine.
biopharmaceutical company focused on the development and commercialization of phospholipids. The company was set-up and financed in 2008 by the EMBL Technology Fund to commercialize the scientific work of Prof. Wolfgang Stremmel, Krehl University Clinic in Heidelberg, Germany.
Please see GastroEnterology2121: Dr Falk's Second Registration Trial of Phosphatidylcholine for UC.

Comments
Thanks Brigitte, So if I understand well, this would not be a substitute to mesalazine, but would be ued in case mesalazine alone is not enough. So it is still consistent with the "step-up approach" used in this disease management, and depending on results, this might delay the start of tnf-alpha inhibitors in the patient treatment pathway. Definetely an interesting topic to follow for the long-term competitive environement of Etiasa in China.
Ferring recently launched CORTIMENT MMX in EU; the company is the licensee in Asia (excluding Japan), Australia, Canada, Latin America and Africa). The product is indicated “ … where 5-ASA treatment is not sufficient”. With Pentasa and Cortiment MMX Ferring is likely to be seen as a partner of choice for the treatment of UC products. In terms of competition with Etiasa, interesting to monitor if the company plans to seek registration for the product in China, and look to market itself or with a partner ?

item.title: Denmark's KRIS Recommends Eisai Lenvima for Thyroid Cancer
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The drug received positive opinion from the EMA in March 2015. Denmark's coordination council for the use of hospital medicine (KRIS) has issued a favourable recommendation supporting use of Eisai (Japan)'s Lenvima (lenvatinib) in patients with thyroid cancer. It is recommended as 1st-line therapy option in Denmark.
The KRIS recommended Lenvima on the basis that the drug had demonstrated a longer rate of disease-free progression compared to a placebo (18.3 months versus 3.6 months).
The KRIS evaluation also concluded that Lenvima produced a statistically significant longer duration of disease-free progression when compared to the current standard of care therapy, namely Bayer (Germany)'s Nexavar (sorafenib) – at 10.8 months versus 5.8 months respectively.
From IHS GlobalInsight

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: FDA Grants Priority Review to AAA Somakit-TATE Diagnostic For NET
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: AAA announced today that the FDA has granted Priority Review to AAA’s New Drug Application (NDA) for SomaKit-TATE, a patented Kit for the preparation of 68Ga-DOTATATE for injection, which is in development to help diagnose and manage somatostatin receptor-positive NET patients using Positron Emission Tomography (PET). The Somakit NDA was submitted on July 1st, 2015 and it is the first NDA ever filed for a drug using Ga-68 as a positron emitter. AAA also announced that the Pivotal Phase III study NETTER-1 met its primary endpoint, demonstrating a statistically significant and clinically meaningful increase in PFS for Lutathera versus double dose of Sandostatin LAR in patients with inoperable midgut NETs. The full data are going to be released at ESMO on Sunday 27th September, Abstract 6LBA, presented by Prof. P. Ruszniewski.
The FDA and the EMA granted Orphan Drug Designation for Ga-68 DOTATATE (Somakit) back in March 2014.
Source: AAA Press Release

item.title: Telesta Reported Prepartion To Establish US Sales Infrastructure For MCNA Launch In 2016
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Telesta published its financial statements and associated Management's Discussion and Analysis for the fiscal year ended June 30 2015. The company's key corporate updates include 1) significant strengthened balance sheet following US private placement and warrant exercise 2) execution of strategic business plan to prepare for the US commercial launch of MCNA in 2016 3) plan to add a US listing for its common shares 4) change in board of directors membership
Financial Statement - A Cash Position to Fund Ongoing Operations of ~$45M
  • The company's cash and near term receivables at June 30 2015 was $6.5 million with an addition of a US led private placement of US $28.6 m and receipt of proceeds of $2.7m from the exercise of $7.4m common share warrants as of September 30 2015.
  • As of September 4, 2015, there were 12.3 million of warrants due to expire before the end of September, 2015, with an exercise price of $0.40 or less. If all of these warrants were to be exercised prior to their maturity, the company would issue an additional 12.3 million shares in return for proceeds of $4.9 million.

Assuming all of these warrants are exercised, Telesta would expect to have a cash position to fund ongoing operations of approximately $45 million, based on current cash resources on hand.

US Launch Readiness For MCNA - To Establish a Lean But Efficient US Sales Infrastructure

Telesta anticipates that its current burn rate will increase significantly, as the Company prepares for the commercial launch of MCNA in 2016. These increased expenditures will include ongoing and new consulting mandates related to the regulatory advancement of MCNA, increased spending at Telesta's manufacturing site, in Montreal Canada, as the facility transitions to commercial production and expenditures related to the establishment of U.S.-based commercial infrastructure, as the Company prepares for commercial launch in 2016.

Change In Board of Directors leadership - Driving Effort to Secure US Listing

Warren Whitehead is a Certified Management Accountant who has held several senior financial management positions with pharmaceutical and biotechnology firms. He is the former CFO of Arius Research Inc., an anti-cancer antibody company (acquired by Roche in 2008), and former CFO of Labopharm Inc. (2000 to 2006) where he led several rounds of financing, including a cross-border NASDAQ offering. Prior positions include CFO of Resolution Pharmaceuticals Inc. and finance and business development at Glaxo Canada (now GlaxoSmithKline).

Source: Telesta Press Release

item.title: Outcomes from a New Report Call for Greater Focus on Adressing QoL of Patients with Prostate Cancer
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The survey was developed by Janssen, in collaboration with patient associations. Entitled Prostate Cancer: Living, not Just Surviving, the report details the findings from a large pan-European survey of 765 prostate cancer patients, 335 caregivers and 400 healthcare professionals (HCP). Professor Louis Denis (Onco-Urologist and Strategic Consultant, Europa Uomo), Hugh Gunn (Patient and Tackle Prostate Cancer Trustee, UK), Calle Waller (Vice Chairman, Prostatacancerförbundet, Sweden)as well as Christian Arnold, Prostate Cancer Survivor and VP of ANAMACAP, France) are referenced in the report. (please see attached).
Outcomes reveal that only 14% of HCP feel that they have sufficient resources to address quality of life issues, such as fatigue, pain and intimacy problems.
The survey reveals that for the patients who experience chronic physical effects from the disease, fatigue (66%) has the biggest negative impact compared to disability and pain (41% and 22% respectively), particularly in metastatic patients (93%) and patients on medication (83%). Almost half of all men with prostate cancer surveyed (n=765) state that they are so tired, they no longer feel able to exercise and 74 per cent of this group say that this has had a negative effect on them emotionally.
It also suggests that men with prostate cancer worry more about quality of life issues associated with their disease, such as intimacy problems (54%) and feeling ill (41%), than dying (36%).
Please find attached the full report @2

  2. Prostate Cancer Living Not Surviving Report Design 08.09.15 - FINAL APPROVED.pdf  (4,8 MB)

item.title: Key Messages from Versartis Investor Symposium
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Ph Backeljauw started the event with a presentation on GH therapy for childhood GHD and current treatment issues in the US. Followed by Jan-Maarten Wit who presented the diagnosis and treatment of GHD from a EU perspective. GH treatment and treatment approaches in Japan were reported by Noriyuk Namba. The event closed with Bradley Miller who spoke about somavaratan PGHD Ph2 experience. On a separate press release issued today, management outlined a potential FDA approval by late 2018 for PGHD.

Company reiterated expectation that it will have top line data on 12-month mean height velocity primary endpoint velocity trial by mid-2017

item.title: PE Met in Ph3 Study of Amgen/UCB's Romosozumab for Osteoporosis
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: UCB has announced that the Ph3 study (STRUCTURE - NCT01796301) met the primary endpoint, demonstrating a statistically significant difference in favor of romosozumab in the percent change of total hip bone mineral density (measured by DXA) through month 12. Further analysis are ongoing and will be submitted to a future medical conference and for publication.
Romosozumab is being studied for its potential to reduce the risk of fractures in an extensive global Ph3 program.
This program includes two large fracture trials comparing romosozumab to either placebo or active comparator in more than 10,000 postmenopausal women with osteoporosis. First results from the Phase 3 study FRAME are expected in H1 2016.
A Ph3 (BRIDGE - NCT02186171) is currently ongoing to compare the efficacy nd safety of romosozumab vs placebo in approx 245 men with osteoporosis (timelines: June / December 2016).
Romosozumab is being co-developed by Amgen and UCB.

The study which began in June 2014 enrolled 500 patients from Germany, Spain, Sweden and the UK . The study is investigating Botox as a second line therapy to oral anticholinergic therapy.

item.title: NCI Funds The First-Ever Specialized SPORE Grant To Study NETs
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: The first-ever Specialized Programs of Research Excellence (SPORE) grant to study neuroendocrine tumors, funded through the National Cancer Institute (NCI), was assigned to the University of Iowa (UI) Holden Comprehensive Cancer Centre researchers. The five year, $10.6 million grant is the only SPORE grant focusing research on neuroendocrine tumors and will fund four major projects to explore the NET genetics, molecular makeup, and how this information can be used to develop new approaches to diagnosis and treatment.
Researchers at Holden Comprehensive Cancer Center are playing significant roles in the new highly collaborative NET SPORE and come from the departments of pediatrics, internal medicine, surgery, radiology, pharmacology, pathology, radiation oncology, epidemiology, biostatistics, chemistry, and biomedical engineering.
Support provided by the Holden Family endowment and the UI Dance Marathon Pediatric Cancer and Blood Disorders Laboratories through the UI Foundation are also contributing to the neuroendocrine tumor research effort at the UI.
Source: UI, NCI

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Raptor's RP103 Disappoints in NASH - Uncertainty on the HD Program
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Raptor has reported that top-line Ph2b results of RP103 failed to meet the PE of improving nonalcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH) in children. Near-term prioities remain on advancing the development of RP103 in Huntington's disease. In 4Q15, the company will provide 36mo data from its Ph2/3 study, along with regulatory clarity on the path to approval. Investors' opinions differ subsequently when it comes to the drug's future. Please see below.
Given that the study failed to meet the primary endpoint, analysts at Wedbush expect the FDA will require another study to be conducted for approval. They are also unimpressed with the benefit observed in the subgroup of HD patients in the study not on concurrent tetrabenazine, since the decline observed with the early-stage HD patients administered RP103 appears to be comparable to the natural decline associated with the disease.
However, analysts at Leerink expect full 36-month data in 4Q15 to include a “delayed start” analysis, which may provide RPTP with a clean slate to make the a case for significantly derisked clinical development or potentially even accelerated approval
Analysts at JMP Securities believe that 36-month data have a chance to show consistent efficacy with the prior 18-month data, although it will likely be more directional than definitive given the absence of placebo in the second part of the study and small sample size. Based on this assumption, we expect the program to advance into a Phase 3 program, which should give investors incremental comfort in the RP-103 potential in Huntington’s

item.title: Takeda to Position Lubiprostone in the IBS-M and IBS-U Subtypes
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: IBS is subclassified according to the predominant bowel habits. These subclassifications are IBS-D, IBS-C, IBS-M, and IBS-U. The newly listed Ph2 in clinicaltrials.gov is currently recruiting participants in the US to evaluate lubiprostone in adult subjects with mixed (M) or unsubtyped (U) IBS. PE will measure overall abdominal pain response. Takeda is looking to position the drug in segments with significant unmet needs, and where patients are the most challenging to manage.
Ref: NCT02544152
Recruitment: Approx 150
  • Subject meets the diagnosis of IBS-M or IBS-U as confirmed using the adapted ROME III Diagnostic Questionnaire for Adult Functional GI Disorders.
  • Subject Screening diary entries must show an average worst abdominal pain in the past 24 hours score of at least 4 on a 11-point scale.
  • Subject must be on a stable dose of selective serotonin re-uptake inhibitors (SSRIs), serotonin-specific reuptake inhibitor (SNRIs), or monoamine oxidase inhibitors (MAO) inhibitors if taking antidepressants.
Timelines: Completion October 2016 / December 2016
PI: Charles Barish, MD Wake Research Associates, LLC

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: BIND Therapeutics' BIND-014 Is Entering Ph2 For Cholangiocarcinoma, Cervical, Advanced Bladder, And H&N Cancer
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: BIND Therapeutics announced patient dosing is underway in the iNSITE 2 trial for four tumour histologies. BIND-014 is an improved docetaxel that utilises PSMA targeted nanoparticle technology. PSMA is a clinically-validated target in prostate cancer and is the target of an FDA-approved imaging agent, ProstaScint, and ADCs currently in clinical development. As part of the Ph2 trial, PSMA expression levels are also characterised as a potential basis for patient selection or a companion diagnostic Stage 1 data readout for the iNSITE 2 trial is expected in the 1H 2016. .
The open-label, phase 2, multi-center two-stage iNSITE 2 clinical trial is designed to determine the activity, safety and tolerability of BIND-014 and will enroll up to 160 patients. In addition, an imaging and biomarker program that can potentially inform the future clinical utility of BIND-014 is also planned.
ClinicalTrials.gov Id: NCT02479178
Study Start Date: June 2015
Estimated Study Completion Date: January 2020
Clinical Evidence presented at the 26th EORTC-NCI-AACR Symposium:
Six patients (5 confirmed, 1 unconfirmed per RECIST v1.1) achieved a partial response (15%, N=40) with a median duration of response of 5.2 months and median progression free survival (PFS) of 2.7 months.
  • Eight patients were enrolled with a confirmed KRAS mutation and two of those eight experienced an objective response (25%); median PFS in patients with KRAS mutant tumors was 2.8 months.
  • In patients with squamous cell carcinoma (n=9) there were no confirmed objective responses; however, median PFS in patients with squamous cell carcinoma was 2.8 months. Prolonged (>4 cycles) disease control was also noted in six of nine (66%) patients with squamous histology.
  • Preliminary median overall survival was 6.2 months for all patients treated, 9.6 months in patients with KRAS mutant tumors and 11.1 months in patients with squamous cell carcinoma.
  • Twenty-one of 40 patients received four or more cycles of therapy, attesting to the tolerability of BIND-014. Consistent with previous results, neutropenia, anemia, neuropathy, and alopecia, commonly observed with docetaxel, were significantly reduced with BIND-014.
Source: BIND Therapeutics Press Release

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: re: CEO of Summit Pharm. Opened to Partner Drug for C.difficile
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
CEO of Summit Pharm. Opened to Partner Drug for C.difficile 
Comment: Last week G. Edwards reported that two Ph3 would take place during 2016, 2017 and possibly into 2018. SMT19969 is an antibiotic selective against CDI that could enable a faster return to normal flora in affected patients. The CDI program was granted Fast Track Designation by the US FDA last month. It is currently in a Ph2 study with data expected in 4Q15, which could facilitate a partnership for Summit.  ...
The company has announced the completion of patient enrolment into the CoDIFy Ph 2 proof of concept trial of SMT19969 for the treatment of CDI. Patient dosing and follow-up is continuing and top-line results are expected in the fourth quarter of 2015.
CoDIFy Phase 2 Clinical Trial - double-blind, randomized, active control Phase 2 trial evaluating the efficacy of SMT19969 against the current standard of care, vancomycin. CoDIFy is being conducted in the United States and Canada. The trial has enrolled a total of 100 patients, with half receiving ten days of dosing with SMT19969, and half receiving ten days of dosing with vancomycin. The primary endpoint of the trial is sustained clinical response, a composite endpoint which is defined as clinical cure at the test of cure visit with no recurrence of CDI within 30 days after the end of treatment. The trial is also examining a number of secondary endpoints, including the safety and tolerability of SMT19969 and its impact on patients' gut microbiome.
About SMT19969 - novel, oral small molecule antibiotic that is being developed specifically for the treatment of CDI

item.title: FDA Granted Fast Track To Biocancell's BC-819 For NMIBC
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: BioCancell announced today that its BC-819 received FDA Fast Track designation for use in non muscle invasive bladdder cancer. BC819 will enter two Ph3 confirmatory studies in 1H 2016. The fast track is being granted for both BCG failure and BCG intolerant patients.
Company Profile
BioCancell's R&D activities build upon the research of Professor Abraham Hochberg of the Hebrew University of Jerusalem. Professor Hochberg isolated the human H19 gene and determined that the gene is expressed in over forty different forms of cancer. H19-based therapy combines a highly selective method of killing cancer cells with a strong safety profile. Each of BioCancell's product candidates relies on a proprietary H19 technology platform, with the potential to provide benefits that are competitive with existing cancer treatment methods. Bladder cancer is the primary focus for the company.
BC-819 , is a double-stranded DNA plasmid construct that uses the H19 gene to activate the synthesis of diphtheria toxin after entering a cell in which H19 transcription factors exist, destroying only that cell. The result of this mechanism is highly selective tumor cell destruction.Two Ph3 trials planned:
  • BCG failure NMIBC: BC819 in combination with BCG in patients who had failed at least one course of BCG. This will be performed under an FDA special protocol assessment
  • BCG unresponsive/intolerant: BC819 monotherapy
In Sept 2014, Biocancell annouced positive results from its Ph2 trial that triggered The company's share price rose 9.5% in afternoon trading on the TASE.
The clinical trials demonstrated for the first time the safety and effectiveness of the combined treatment including BCG on high-risk bladder cancer patients. 17 patients were treated in the trial with three treatments regimens, following removal of all the malignant tumours in the bladder.
The results of the trial were that 11 of the 17 patients (65%) had no recurrence of the malignant tumor for three months from the beginning of the treatment. No severe side effects related to the treatment were diagnosed during the trial.
Source: marketwire press release

Add a Comment on this Article

item.title: Versartis Initiates POC With Monthly rhGH for AGHD
item.dc:creator: spoon
item.content:encoded:
Comment: Today, Versartis announced the initiation of the VITAL trial, an open-label, international, multicenter study with somavaratan treatment for 5 months. Secondary endpoints is tracking the measurement and detection of neutralizing antibodies (not included in the VELOCITY trial). Expected VITAL data in mid-2016, with potential for filing by 2019. In parallel, the company reported the appointment of Lars Ekman as a consultant for its clinical development strategy. Next week, management will hold an Investor Symposium. The agenda features a panel of internationally renowned Ped endocrinologists, such as Ph Backeljauw, who will shares their perspectives, experiences and insights regarding pediatric GHD.
Ref NCT02526420
Recruitment: approx 40 (Subjects will be stratified into three cohorts based on age, gender and the use of oral estrogens)
Timelines: June 2016 / August 2016
This treatment period will include monthly dose titrations until a subject's mean IGF-I SDS value is within a target range for two consecutive months. Subjects will be stratified into three cohorts based on age, gender and the use of oral estrogens.
Location: USA (4 active sites); EU and Australia (tbc)
Dr. Ekman is currently an Executive Partner at Sofinnova Ventures, and has more than 28 years in senior executive, scientific and clinical functions.
Most recently, he was appointed to the Board of Directors of Poseida Therapeutics. He is Chairman of the Amarin Corporation, plc, The Prothena Corporation, plc, and Sophiris Bio, Inc., and he also serves on the Board of Directors of Spark Therapeutics, Inc.
Previously, Dr. Ekman held the position of President of Research and Development at Elan Corporation, plc. Dr. Ekman joined Elan in January 2001, and he is credited with advancing Elan's pipeline during this period.
